{"uri": "8116605976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:59:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:59:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:58:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2931400-pga-championship-extends-invitations-to-liv-players-meeting-world-ranking-criteria", "title": "PGA Championship Extends Invitations to LIV Players Meeting World Ranking Criteria | Sports-Games", "body": "The PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major 99 of the 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.The PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major 99 of the 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria. Those hopes ended late Tuesday when Rikuya Hoshino (No. 94) withdrew.\n\nThe PGA leans on a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had been invited.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert and Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Alex Smalley.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8116576009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:25:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:25:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:25:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://azdailysun.com/pga-championship-invites-7-liv-players-to-get-top-100-in-the-world/article_59a39fe6-502d-5ee7-86e1-d59b6c2dcf46.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites 7 LIV players to get top 100 in the world", "body": "Rory McIlroy, left, of Northern Ireland, and Joaquin Niemann, of Chile, walks off the 18th hole after final round at the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club Sunday, April 14, 2024, in Augusta, Ga.\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major 99 of the 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria. Those hopes ended late Tuesday when Rikuya Hoshino (No. 94) withdrew.\n\nThe PGA leans on a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had been invited.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert and Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Alex Smalley.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf\n\nCopy article link", "source": {"uri": "azdailysun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arizona Daily Sun"}, "authors": {"uri": "8116605974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:59:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:59:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:58:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2931402-pga-championship-extends-invitations-to-7-liv-golfers-in-pursuit-of-world-ranking-eligibility", "title": "PGA Championship extends invitations to 7 LIV golfers in pursuit of world ranking eligibility | Sports-Games", "body": "The PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major 99 of the 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria. Those hopes ended late Tuesday when Rikuya Hoshino (No. 94) withdrew.\n\nThe PGA leans on a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had been invited.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert and Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Alex Smalley.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-05-348211928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "20:42:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T20:42:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:24:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/7/pga-championship-invites-seven-liv-players-to-get-/", "title": "PGA Championship invites 7 LIV players to get top 100 in the world", "body": "The PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago. Among those left off the list was former British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen, who won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour. He is No. 125 in the world.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals - 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. {"uri": "2024-05-348011108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:40:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:40:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:24:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.wsiltv.com/news/kentucky/pga-championship-invites-7-liv-players-to-get-top-100-in-the-world/article_62c809ea-519c-50f1-b538-6f2a1d188110.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites 7 LIV players to get top 100 in the world", "body": "The PGA Championship field next week at Valhalla includes everyone from the top 100 in the world\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago. Among those left off the list was former British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen, who won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour. He is No. 125 in the world.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf", "source": {"uri": "wsiltv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WSIL"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-348019607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:49:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:49:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:24:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-05-07/pga-championship-invites-7-liv-players-to-get-top-100-in-the-world", "title": "PGA Championship Invites 7 LIV Players to Get Top 100 in the World", "body": "The PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago. Among those left off the list was former British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen, who won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour. He is No. 125 in the world.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8116612260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "04:05:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T04:05:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T04:04:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-pga-championship-invites-7-liv-players-to-get-top-100-in-the-world-5948821.html", "title": "Sports News | PGA Championship Invites 7 LIV Players to Get Top 100 in the World | LatestLY", "body": "Louisville (US), May 8 (AP) The PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major 99 of the 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria. Those hopes ended late Tuesday when Rikuya Hoshino (No. 94) withdrew.\n\nAlso Read | Athletic Bilbao Striker Gorka Guruzeta Undergoes Appendix Operation, Will Miss Rest of La Liga 2023-24 Season.\n\nThe PGA leans on a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nAlso Read | Pat Cummins Birthday Special: Quick Facts to Know About ICC Cricket World Cup and WTC Winning Captain.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had been invited.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert and Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Alex Smalley. {"uri": "8115946535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:40:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:40:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:39:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/national/pga-championship-invites-7-liv-players-to-get-top-100-in-the-world/article_8c8a3cfc-5fbb-5aa2-91a2-34f5fb049638.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites 7 LIV players to get top 100 in the world", "body": "Rory McIlroy, left, of Northern Ireland, and Joaquin Niemann, of Chile, walks off the 18th hole after final round at the Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club Sunday, April 14, 2024, in Augusta, Ga.\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago. Among those left off the list was former British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen, who won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour. He is No. 125 in the world.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf", "source": {"uri": "idahostatejournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Idaho State Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-347827972", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:02:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:02:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T13:38:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.aol.com/pga-championship-tiger-woods-livs-133848185.html", "title": "PGA Championship: Tiger Woods, LIV's Talor Gooch in the field at Valhalla", "body": "PGA Championship: Tiger Woods, LIV's Talor Gooch in the field at ValhallaJay BusbeeMay 7, 2024 at 3:38 PM\n\nTiger Woods will return to golf next week at the PGA Championship. The PGA of America has announced the field for next week's major at Valhalla, and Woods -- a four-time winner of the event, most recently in 2007 -- is listed among the contenders. The field includes 16 prior PGA champions and 33 major champions.\n\nIt also includes a LIV Golf champion -- Talor Gooch, who won LIV's individual title last season. Gooch had been outspoken in his condemnation of the majors for not inviting LIV players to their events, so much so that he won't even attempt to qualify for the U.S. Open or Open Championship.\n\nThe PGA of America, which has taken a more evenhanded approach toward LIV players than some other entities, decided to extend Gooch a special exemption, in addition to the invitation it made earlier to LIV's Joaquin Niemann. Neither Gooch nor Niemann qualified for the PGA under its typical qualification processes, which include victories on the PGA Tour or high standing in the Official World Golf Rankings. LIV's three-round, no-cut tournaments do not receive points from the OWGR, meaning LIV players do not have the opportunity to improve their rankings.\n\nMany LIV players had already qualified their way into the PGA Championship, either through prior victories at the PGA Championship -- like Phil Mickelson and defending champion Brooks Koepka -- or through strong performance at other recent majors, like Jon Rahm (2023 Masters winner), Cam Smith (2022 Open winner), Dustin Johnson (2020 Masters winner) and Bryson DeChambeau (2020 U.S. Open winner).\n\nAlso in the field: Michael Block, the PGA club pro who launched himself into history last year when he carded an ace, played alongside Rory McIlroy, and finished in the Top 15 at Oak Hill. That performance changed his life, and he'll be one of the stories to watch this year.\n\nBlock and 20 other club pros will round out the full field this year. Six will be playing in their first PGA Championship of their careers. Two spots will be reserved for winners at this week's PGA Tour events, the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic, if they are not already qualified.\n\nThe PGA Championship will take place May 16-19 at Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville. Previous PGA Championships at Valhalla took place in 1996 (winner: Mark Brooks), 2000 (Woods) and 2014 (McIlroy). {"uri": "8116312913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:05:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:05:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:05:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/sports/professional/pga/golf-pga-championship-liv-tour-tiger-woods-reed-valhalla-louisville/article_021f96f5-8c52-5166-b7e9-79efcdde2ee8.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0 Tags Dcc Wire Lee-national * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "nwitimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "nwi.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_j_phillip@nwitimes.com", "name": "David J. {"uri": "8115733686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:21:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:21:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T14:20:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.si.com/golf/2024/05/07/2024-pga-championship-full-field", "title": "2024 PGA Championship Field Includes Tiger Woods, All of World's Top 100 Players", "body": "The field is out for next week's PGA Championship, and as expected the top 100 players in the Official World Golf Ranking are all on the list.\n\nActually, the top 103 in the world are in the 156-player field for Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Ky., as well as a couple of intriguing names at No. 644 and No. 801 in the world.\n\nNo. 801 is Tiger Woods, the four-time PGA champion who won in 2000 at Valhalla in a thrilling playoff over Bob May. Woods set the consecutive-cuts-made record last month at the Masters before fading on the weekend to 60th, but left Augusta National optimistic for the rest of the majors this season. He accepted a special exemption to the U.S. Open last week.\n\nNo. 644 is LIV Golf's Talor Gooch, who confirmed his special exemption from the PGA of America on Monday via his social media. His spot appears to underline the PGA of America's desire to have the strongest possible field in its major; Gooch was a three-time winner and LIV Golf's player of the year in 2023.\n\nLIV Golf's David Puig and Dean Burmester also received exemptions. Puig has won twice on the Asian Tour in the last seven months and is 106th in the world, while Burmester won back-to-back DP World tour events to end 2023 and won on LIV last month in Miami.\n\nThere are 15 LIV golfers in the field. Brooks Koepka is the defending PGA champion, a three-time PGA winner overall and coming in off a win last week in Singapore. Bryson DeChambeau, Dustin Johnson, Martin Kaymer, Phil Mickelson, Patrick Reed and Cameron Smith are other past major champions from LIV Golf in the field.\n\nScottie Scheffler, the world No. 1 who won last month at the Masters, is scheduled to compete but is on baby watch at home with wife Meredith. He is skipping this week's Wells Fargo Championship, a signature event on the PGA Tour.\n\nAs usual, the field also includes 20 PGA professionals who qualified via the annual PGA Professional Championship. The total PGA professional count is 21, as Michael Block returns after a T15 finish last year at Oak Hill which earned him a spot at Valhalla.\n\nThe winners of this week's Wells Fargo and Myrtle Beach Classic on the PGA Tour will receive spots in the field if they're not in already.\n\nBelow is the full field for the the PGA Championship, which is May 16-19.", "source": {"uri": "si.com", {"uri": "8115945549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:38:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:38:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:38:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://wtop.com/national/2024/05/pga-championship-invites-7-liv-players-to-get-top-100-in-the-world/", "title": "PGA Championship invites 7 LIV players to get top 100 in the world - WTOP News", "body": "The PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded...\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago. Among those left off the list was former British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen, who won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour. He is No. 125 in the world.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Koepka also won the tournament in 2018 and 2019 and is in good form ahead of his defence after triumphing at last week's LIV event in Singapore.\n\nWoods, a 15-time major champion, won the PGA Championship in 1999, 2000, 2006 and 2007, while world No 2 McIlroy emerged victorious in 2012 and 2014. The four-time major winner has yet to win a major since that 2014 tournament which was held at the very same Valhalla Golf Club in Kentucky. A good omen, perhaps?\n\nThere is also the opportunity for Jordan Spieth to complete the career Grand Slam, the 30-year-old needing the Wanamaker Trophy to complete his set after his victories at The Masters and US Open in 2015 and The Open two years later.\n\nWorld No 5 Jon Rahm joins Koepka as part of a strong LIV Golf contingent named, which also includes former Open champion Cameron Smith and English hopeful Tyrrell Hatton.\n\nThey are among the 154 golfers named in the field by the PGA of America, with two remaining spots reserved for the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and Myrtle Beach Classic. Should a golfer who is already exempt emerge victorious at either event, additional players will be chosen from the alternates list.\n\nLIV Golf features 16 players in this year's PGA Championship field, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nAlong with Koepka, Rahm, Smith and Hatton mentioned above, that number includes seven 'special invitations' being extended to players from the Saudi-backed tour, ensuring that golf's entire top 100 in the world rankings will feature at Valhalla.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the world's top 100 participate in the tournament in order to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors.\n\nThe PGA has used the catch-all category of 'special invitations' to include the likes of Patrick Reed, Joaquin Niemann and Talor Gooch.\n\n2018 Masters champion Reed's tied 12th finish at Augusta National this year moved him inside the top 100 to 92nd, while Niemann won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins to his name this year.\n\nGooch announced in a post on X on Monday, prior to the field being officially announced, that he had received an invitation.\n\nHis selection is perhaps a sign that the PGA of America's selection committee are looking specifically at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside of the Saudi league. He won three LIV events in 2023 on his way to topping their season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, and Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world, and David Puig at 106th in the rankings.\n\nThere might have been one more LIV golfer to feature, but for the fact former Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation due to \"personal commitments\", according to his manager.\n\nWatch the PGA Championship, exclusively live on Sky Sports Golf from May 16-19. {"uri": "8116241516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "20:52:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T20:52:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T20:52:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/07/pga-championship-field-gets-all-of-top-100-with-7-special-invitations-to-liv-players/", "title": "PGA Championship field gets all of top 100 with 7 special invitations to LIV players", "body": "The PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European Tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals - 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nSINCE JOINING LIV, Gooch has played just two events that weren't on that circuit or were a major, and he didn't have a good result in either. He answered a question last week about potentially playing in qualifying events for the U.S. Open and British Open by bluntly indicating he had no intention of doing so.\n\nGooch sparked derision in golf circles earlier this year when he was quoted as saying of the 2024 Masters - to which he was not invited - \"If Rory McIlroy goes and completes his (career) Grand Slam without some of the best players in the world, there's just going to be an asterisk. It's just the reality. I think everybody wins whenever the majors figure out a way to get the best players in the world there.\" The Masters field ended up including 13 other LIV players, raising questions about whether Gooch's criterion for \"the best players in the world\" was a field with him in it.\n\nAs such, Gooch could find himself feeling an extra dose of pressure to perform well at the PGA Championship, which tees off next week. A one-time winner on the PGA Tour, he is coming off a fourth-place finish at a LIV event in Singapore.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. Updated list explored", "body": "The 2024 PGA Championship has published the official list of players that will compose the field of the event. A total of 16 LIV Golf players are in the field, including several special invitations that surprised many.\n\nAfter six LIV golfers received special invitations to the PGA Championship on Monday, May 6, the list of players managed by Greg Norman who will be in Valhalla is as follows:\n\nThere are seven LIV Golf players who landed in the 2024 PGA Championship field thanks to special invitations. Joaquin Niemann received it in early March, while Talor Gooch, David Puig, Adrian Meronk, Patrick Reed, Dean Burmester, and Lucas Herbert received them on Monday.\n\nPhil Mickelson, Brooks Koepka and Martin Kaymer are exempt for having won the PGA Championship before. In Koepka's case, he comes in as the defending champion.\n\nBryson DeChambeau, Dustin Johnson, Jon Rahm, and Cameron Smith, meanwhile, are exempt for having won any of the other three Majors in the last five years. Tyrrell Hatton's exemption is due to qualifying for last season's PGA Tour TOUR Championship.\n\nThe final case is that of Andy Ogletree, who earned a spot in the 2024 PGA Championship thanks to being included in the top 3 of the International Federation Official World Golf Ranking List.\n\nThis is an initiative launched in 2023 to include in the event the top three ranked players in the world who play primarily on the Asian Tour, Japan Golf Tour, PGA Tour of Australasia, and the Sunshine Tour.\n\nA look at the rest of the PGA Championship field\n\nThe PGA Championship field will be made up of 156 players. In addition to the 16 LIV players, the following are already confirmed:\n\nOnly two positions in the field are pending to be defined. This will occur after the completion of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic this week, as the winners qualify for the PGA Championship. {"uri": "8115825006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:18:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:18:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:18:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.outkick.com/sports/pga-championship-field-strongest-major-championships-liv-golf-invites", "title": "PGA Championship Leans Into Having Strongest Field In Majors With LIV Invites", "body": "The PGA Championship is the most-overlooked major in professional golf. That's a peculiar fact, however, given that it regularly has the strongest overall tournament field among the four majors, and in 2024 it's clear that the PGA is leaning into that advantage.\n\nThe PGA Championship is the only major championship that does not explicitly invite amateur players to compete. Instead, the PGA of America welcomes the top PGA professionals into the field via their qualifying through the PGA Professional Championship or an exemption from their performance in the previous year's tournament.\n\nThe PGA Championship has two other key factors it can use to its advantage as well in today's modern game: field size and special invites.\n\nThe Masters, for example, features the smallest field of all major championships, with fewer than 90 players teeing it up in last month's tournament, including five amateurs. The PGA Championship is essentially a completely opposite setup as it reserves the right to have a 156-player field.\n\nWith the additional spots to be awarded to professionals and the simple fact that the PGA of America can invite whoever it pleases - just as golf's other governing bodies can as well - it awards the PGA Championship the opportunity to essentially invite as many LIV players that it sees fit, and it's taken full advantage this year.\n\nThe field for next week's PGA Championship at Valhalla was released on Tuesday, and there were far more LIV players on the official list than many expected.\n\nSix LIV players who were not qualified for the PGA Championship received special invites from the PGA of America, including Talor Gooch, Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, Patrick Reed, and David Puig. In total, 15 LIV golfers are expected to tee it up at Valhalla.\n\nThe Masters featured just 13 LIV players, with Joaquin Niemann being the lone player from the Saudi-backed circuit to receive a special invite from Augusta National.\n\nWhile the six LIV players who received invites to play in this year's PGA Championship don't necessarily 'move the needle,' all six are undoubtedly among the 156 best players in the world. According to Data Golf, Herbert is the lowest-ranked player among invites sitting at 124th in its ranking system.\n\nWhile the PGA of America nor the PGA Championship will boast about being 'the major with the most LIV players in the field,' it's a no-brainer decision for them to give spots to as many LIV golfers they see fit while further solidifying themselves as having the strongest field of all the major championships.", "source": {"uri": "outkick.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "OutKick"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mark_harris@outkick.com", "name": "Mark Harris", "type": "author", "isAgency": He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago. Among those left off the list was former British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen, who won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour. The players deserve the respect and should have received it from day one.\"\n\nThe PGA of America invited Gooch based on his performance at LIV Golf. He received no invitation to the Masters held in April and was also restricted from participating at the US Open last year due to an error.\n\nTalor Gooch earned $39.5 million from individual competitions along with an additional bonus of $18 million for ranking first as an individual at the end of the edition.\n\nLIV golfers will compete at the US PGA Championship at Valhalla\n\nThe 2024 PGA Championship will be held from May 16-19, 2024 at Valhalla Golf Club in Kentucky. PGA of America announced the full field that will be seen competing at Valhalla next week, with two spots reserved for winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and Myrtle Beach Classic.\n\nLIV golfers Talor Gooch, Dean Burmester, Adrian Meronk, Lucas Herbert, David Puig and Patrick Reed will also be spotted as they have received exemptions to participate in the PGA Championship.\n\nOf all the players, Burmester has had the most success, winning back-to-back DP World Tour events in 2023 followed by his first LIV Golf title in Miami, propelling him to third place in the rankings for the season.\n\nThe one noticeable name missing from the LIV golf's list of invitations appears to be Louis Oosthuizen. He had two wins in the DP World Tour at the end of 2023 and finished runner-up twice in the breakaway league this year.\n\nThere will be a total of 15 LIV Golf players playing in the field of the US PGA Championship, which is two more than last month's Masters.\n\nLast year, Seth Waugh, the CEO of the PGA Championship, dismissed LIV's long-term viability and said (via bunkered.co.uk):\n\n\"I don't think people really care about it, And I don't see how it's a survivable business model. They can fund it for as long as they want to, but no matter how much money you have, at some point, burning it doesn't feel very good.\n\n\"I don't see they are accomplishing much. It seems logical to me, then, that you would work towards some sort of agreement. I hope the game comes back together in some form.\"\n\nGoing from that to offering 15 spots to LIV golfers, it seems like this year will be considered a significant victory for the Saudi league.", "title": "Shock PGA move sparks LIV invasion as rogue Aussie's nod ushers in new era", "body": "Aussie Lucas Herbert is among a whopping seven LIV Golf players to earn special invites to next week's PGA Championship, the second major of the year, in what could be a shock thawing of ongoing tensions in the fractured golfing landscape.\n\nInvitations into majors, which have strict qualification rules, for LIV players have been a bone of contention with very few ever given out.\n\nThis year's Masters saw Augusta National break the mould by offering special invites to the in-form Joaquin Niemann and Adrian Meronk -- the past two Australian Open winners.\n\nThe only place to watch every upcoming event on the Challenger PGA Tour of Australasia live is on Fox Sports, available on Kayo >\n\nNow PGA officials have broken down the walls further by rapidly expanding its own invite list to include Herbert along with fellow LIV stars Patrick Reed, Niemann, Dean Burmester, Meronk and David Puig.\n\nAn invitation was also offered to 2010 British Open winner Louis Oosthuizen, who declined due to a prior commitment, emphasising, perhaps, the surprise of the invitation.\n\nDespite his claims the Masters winners for the past two years should have an \"asterisk\" next to their names without all LIV players being eligible, and having refused to attend US Open qualifying, Talor Gooch, a four-time LIV winner, also earnt a PGA invite as officials attempt to assemble the best field possible amid golf's divided landscape.\n\nLIV chief Greg Norman was swift to applaud the move, saying: \"The only influence is the success of LIV, our players, our penetration/acceptance and our platform. The players deserve the respect and should have received it from day one.\"\n\nHerbert, who joined the all-Australian Ripper GC this season and has tasted team success at the past two LIV events, will be one of six Australians in the field at Valhalla.\n\nHe'll join 2015 PGA winner Jason Day, Min Woo Lee, Cam Davis, Adam Scott and his LIV team captain Cam Smith, who needs a podium finish at least to get the rankings points boost he needs to keep his Olympic hopes alive.\n\nThere will be 16 LIV players in PGA field, which includes the world's 103 top-ranked golfers, and Tiger Woods.\n\nIt means that the major will be a true meeting of the best male golfers, something which fans have been starved of since the emergence of LIV Golf in 2022.\n\nHowever, given the PGA Tour is run separately from the year's four majors, the golf world is still a long way off achieving re-unification.\n\n\"Here's the thing: the majors were always gonna be fine,\" wrote PGA Tour insider Dan Rapaport. \"They can invite who they want. The Champions League of golf.\n\n\"It's the week-to-week product that suffers with this divide.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Woods, a 15-time major winner, has struggled to walk four rounds in tournaments since suffering severe leg injuries in a 2021 car crash but finished 60th in last month's Masters and says he hopes to play once a month through the US and British Opens.\n\nWoods, ranked 801, has accepted a special invitation into next month's US Open. He withdrew after three rounds in 2022 in his most recent PGA Championship start, skipping last year after ankle surgery.\n\nWoods and four-time major winner Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland have each won PGA Championship titles at Valhalla -- Woods in 2000 and McIlroy in 2014 in his most recent major triumph.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 major winners, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners.\n\nTwo vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe line-up includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title last month, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings.\n\nScheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby.\n\nThe field includes 21 club professionals, 20 qualifiers and Michael Block, who returns after sharing 15th last year at The tournament will be played from May 16-19 at Valhalla Golf Course. Woods has won the tournament four times in his career - 1999, 2006, 2006, and 2007 as well.\n\nA total of 156 players will be participating in the tournament with PGA of America releasing 154 names. The rest two spots will go to the winners of Wells Fargo Championship and Myrtle Beach Classic. The tournament field includes 16 former winners and 33 major winners as well.\n\nAlso Read: San Antonio Spurs' Victor Wembanyama named unanimous Rookie of the Year\n\nApart from Woods, defending champion Brooks Koepka, Rory McIlroy and current world number one Scottie Scheffler will also take part in the prestigious tournament. The field also includes LIV Golf's Talor Gooch who had won the former rival tour's individual title last season.\n\nPGA of America has been level headed in their approach to LIV Golf players after it was announced in the June last year that LIV and PGA would merge to become one single entity.\n\nGooch has been extended an special invitation to play in the major as he doesn't qualify under the regular qualification process which requires high ranking in the Official World Golf Rankings (OWGR) or winning on the PGA Tour.\n\nNotably, LIV Golf players do not receive points from LIV tournament hence their ranking doesn't improve on OWGR. Some of the LIV players, however, qualified for this year's PGA Championship on the basis of their previous victory like Koepka and Phil Mickelson.\n\nA few of the LIV players have also qualified to Currently ranked 801 in the world, Woods had previously accepted a special invitation into next month's US Open after the US Golf Association announced last week that the three-time tournament champion had been awarded an exemption in order to compete at Pinehurst.\n\nThe American finished 60th, last among those who made the cut, in last month's Masters, yet completed 72 holes in a major for the first time since his 2022 Masters comeback. Since 2013, Woods has finished 72 holes at the US Open only once, taking 21st in 2019, only two months after winning the Masters. He missed the cut in 2015, 2018 and 2020 and did not play in the remaining years. The last time he played in the PGA Championship in 2022, he withdrew after three rounds, skipping last year after ankle surgery.\n\nWoods and four-time major winner Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland have each won PGA Championship titles at Valhalla, who will host the tournament for the fourth time on May 16-19. The American won in 2000 and McIlroy celebrated in 2014, his most recent major triumph.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 major winners, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners. Two vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe lineup includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title last month, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings. Scheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby. Defending champion Brooks Koepka of the United States is among 16 players from the LIV Golf League who will compete in the year's second major tournament.\n\nOther LIV players from the world's top 100 include fifth-ranked Jon Rahm, England's 17th-ranked Tyrrell Hatton, Australia's Cameron Smith and Lucas Herbert, Poland's Adrian Meronk, Chile's Joaquin Niemann and American Patrick Reed. Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, figures to contend, while 94-ranked Rikuya Hoshino withdrew.\n\nBryson DeChambeau, Phil Mickelson, Dustin Johnson and Martin Kaymer are also among those who have won in LIV events. American Talor Gooch, last year's LIV season champion, was surprisingly invited into his fifth consecutive PGA Championship. His best result was a share of 20th in 2022 but he missed the cut last year.\n\nThe field includes 21 club professionals, 20 qualifiers and Michael Block, who returns after sharing 15th last year at {"uri": "8116317103", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:10:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:10:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:09:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/golf-pga-championship-liv-tour-tiger-woods-reed-valhalla-louisville/article_42bfe8c0-96ba-5d65-9bd3-157bfe982aa2.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois Suspect in Heartland college carjacking granted pretrial release Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Pitching talents of Pontiac's Henry Brummel attracting professional scouts Normal man detained in home invasion, sexual assault case\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "pantagraph.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "pantagraph.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_j_phillip@pantagraph.com", "name": "David J. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, and Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in his home country of South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour. His manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of this weekend's Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field in the Wells Fargo at Quail Hollow in Charlotte, N.C., have not qualified.
