{"uri": "8115809248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:09:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:09:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:09:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/golf/liv-golf-pga-championship-gooch-32755336", "title": "7 LIV stars earn PGA Championship invite as Gooch and Reed handed major lifeline", "body": "Seven LIV Golf stars have been handed invites to compete in next week's PGA Championship at Valhalla, including Talor Gooch and Patrick Reed.\n\nThe second major of the campaign will get underway in Kentucky next week, with 15 members from the breakaway league teeing it up alongside their PGA Tour and DP World Tour rivals. The biggest being defending champion Brooks Koepka, who heads to Valhalla having won his third PGA Championship at Oak Hill last year.\n\nOver half of the LIV quota heading to the event received invites from the PGA of America to compete, with their representation at the top of the world rankings dwindling amid the Saudi league's lack Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR) recognition.\n\nREAD MORE: Luke Donald's Ryder Cup preparation speaks volumes amid Tiger Woods uncertainty\n\nREAD MORE: Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy overcome LIV Golf problem as TGL replacement for Jon Rahm confirmed\n\nThe most notable name on the invite list is that of Gooch, who was initially ineligible to compete in any of the four majors in 2024 despite being crowned 2023 LIV champion last campaign. Including the American, here is a look at the seven invitees from the breakaway circuit.\n\nTalor Gooch\n\nStarting with Gooch, the LIV champion will compete at the PGA Championship for the fifth time in his career. He looked set to miss the trip to Kentucky thanks to his fall down the world rankings, with the three-time LIV winner currently sat in 644th in the list.\n\nThe Smash star has been vocal about his lack of major opportunity on the back of his career-best form on the Saudi-backed series, and he has finally been listened to by the powers that be at the PGA of America. Gooch's PGA Championship form is: CUT, T44, T20, CUT.\n\nPatrick Reed\n\nThe next big name to bank a PGA invite is Reed. Reed had announced himself as one of the best players in the world in the late 2010's, capping things off by being crowned Masters champion at Augusta National in 2018. His exemption as a major winner for this event ran out this year though, and with his own fall in the world rankings, he has been forced to rely on an invite this time around.\n\nFor all the latest on news, politics, sports, and showbiz from the USA, go to The Mirror US.\n\nPatrick Reed is heading to the PGA Championship\n\nReed has a solid record in the PGA Championship, boasting five top-20 finishes in nine outings, missing the cut just twice. His best performance came in 2017, when the LIV Golf star finished in a tie for second, two shots behind eventual champion Justin Thomas.\n\nJoaquin Niemann\n\nAlso on the LIV invite list is Joaquin Niemann. Niemann has more than made a name for himself in recent months, venturing away from the breakaway circuit in a bid to earn himself a spot in the four majors, which came with some success. After impressing throughout the end of 2023 and start of 2024, the Torque GC star was handed an invite to compete in last month's Masters.\n\nAnd this was mirrored by the PGA of America, after the current LIV Order of Merit leader was gifted a spot in next week's field. Niemann will also compete in the Open Championship in July, after he earned a place at Royal Troon after winning the Australian Open in December.\n\nAdrian Meronk\n\nNext on the list is a man who also competed in last month's Masters in Adrian Meronk. The 2023 DP World Tour Player of The Year is one of LIV Golf's latest recruits after making the Saudi switch in February this year, but like many, Meronk has already felt the effects of his move.\n\nHaving battled his way into the top-50 in the world rankings at the end of 2023, the Pole has now slipped back in the list, currently sitting 63rd. He will however still compete against the world's best in Kentucky next week, playing the PGA Championship for the second time in his career.\n\nAdrian Meronk has been invited to the PGA Championship David Puig\n\nOne LIV Golf star who will be making his debut at the PGA Championship is the in-form David Puig. Puig opted to turn to professional out of college in order to join the breakaway league, but it is efforts on the Asian Tour that have caught the eye of many.\n\nSince last season's International Series England event, Puig has three top-20s, four top 10s, and two victories on the Asian circuit, which has seen him move towards breaking into the top-100 in the world for the first time. His form has since been rewarded with an invite to Valhalla.\n\nLucas Herbert\n\nJoining Puig and co will be Lucas Herbert, who is another one of LIV's latest recruits. Joining Cam Smith's Ripper GC team in January, Herbert had previously played his golf across the PGA Tour and DP World Tour before committing to the Saudi-funded league. This however will not stop him making his fifth consecutive PGA Championship start, after being included on Tuesday's entry list.\n\nDean Burmester\n\nThe final invite handed out to those on the breakaway circuit came the way of Dean Burmester. The South African has impressed both on and off the LIV circuit so far this season, winning the Joburg Open on his return to the DP World Tour last November, before adding his first ever LIV Golf title in Miami last month.\n\nThese efforts have also been rewarded by the PGA of America, who have handed the big-hitting South African the chance to play in the second major championship of the year for the fourth-straight year.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "joshua_lees@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Joshua Lees", "type": "author", {"uri": "8118598933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:42:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:42:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:37:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/pga-championship-invites-seven-liv-players/article_0cf8a418-23de-5c72-b076-7261ea05ea5e.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON\n\nAssociated Press\n\nGOLF\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria. Those hopes ended late Tuesday when Rikuya Hoshino (No. 94) withdrew.\n\nThe PGA leans on a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... Former McDowell man serving life sentence for murder killed in prison Former McDowell High School counselor charged with sex acts on a student makes court appearance Work begins to renovate McDowell County's Rec Center Man sentenced to prison for second-degree murder in Marion Marion couple charged with child abuse appear in court McDowell shortstop Eli Elliott signs to play with Ferrum College Couple charged by McDowell Sheriff's Office with theft Burke teen killed in Hildebran crash Woman's condition deteriorated quickly after fatal dose of insulin. Winston-Salem nurse charged with murder Marion police officers make arrests for narcotics Inmate charged with malicious conduct MTCC to hold two graduation ceremonies this year McDowell family grateful for help during girl's medical crisis This Week in MHS Sports: Playoffs begin for most spring sports Lower Heartbreak Ridge Trail opens in Old Fort\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nTags Sports Games And Toys Golf Music Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. {"uri": "2024-05-348933496", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:36:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:36:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T21:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/sports/professional/golf-pga-championship-liv-tour-tiger-woods-reed-valhalla-louisville/article_57afa3e6-ba74-5d1e-aad5-d27139faf5ed.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria. Those hopes ended late Tuesday when Rikuya Hoshino (No. 94) withdrew.\n\nThe PGA leans on a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nWentzville superintendent's departure came after threats and police patrols Busch Stadium needs renovations. Should St. Louis taxpayers kick in? Pro-Palestinian protests block traffic outside Washington University BenFred: Sunday was a gut-test game for the Cardinals. They failed. Miserably. Teen charged with breaking into more than 35 cars in St. Louis County St. Louis County man charged with 1966 Chicago killing, stabbing woman 125 times Target to open this summer in Midtown St. Louis neighborhood Billions of cicadas are on their way. They'll appear by early next week in the St. Louis area. Cardinals catcher Willson Contreras in agony after bat fractures his left forearm Hochman: For Cardinals fans, 'patience' has become a 'trigger word' on social media Condemnation mounts for Washington University's 'appalling' response to protest Media Views: Battlehawks dominate spring football in attendance, but no longer in TV ratings Cardinals games dropped by Comcast after Bally Sports deal falls through St. Louis commission dethrones chair after 'unacceptable' remarks to staffer Messenger: Chair of St. Louis homeless board is absent, with questions about her past bills\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\n0 Comments Tags Dcc Wire Lee-national\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_j_phillip@stltoday.com", "name": "David J. {"uri": "2024-05-348161740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "19:33:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T19:33:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:04:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/sports/20240507-tiger-and-world-s-top-100-named-in-pga-championship-field", "title": "Tiger and world's top 100 named in PGA Championship field", "body": "Washington (AFP) - Tiger Woods and the world's 103 top-ranked golfers were among those named Tuesday as the field was announced for next week's 106th PGA Championship at Valhalla.\n\nWoods, a 15-time major winner, has struggled to walk four rounds in tournaments since suffering severe leg injuries in a 2021 car crash but finished 60th in last month's Masters and says he hopes to play once a month through the US and British Opens.\n\nWoods, ranked 801, has accepted a special invitation into next month's US Open.\n\nHe withdrew after three rounds in 2022 in his most recent PGA Championship start, skipping last year after ankle surgery.\n\nWoods and four-time major winner Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland have each won PGA Championship titles at Valhalla -- Woods in 2000 and McIlroy in 2014 in his most recent major triumph.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 major winners, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners.\n\nTwo vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe lineup includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title last month, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings.\n\nScheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby.\n\nDefending champion Brooks Koepka of the United States is among 16 players from the LIV Golf League who will compete in the year's second major tournament.\n\nOther LIV players from the world's top 100 include fifth-ranked Jon Rahm, England's 17th-ranked Tyrrell Hatton, Australia's Cameron Smith and Lucas Herbert, Poland's Adrian Meronk, Chile's Joaquin Niemann and American Patrick Reed.\n\nOther major winners from LIV include Bryson DeChambeau, Phil Mickelson, Dustin Johnson and Martin Kaymer.\n\nAmerican Talor Gooch, last year's LIV season champion, was invited into his fifth consecutive PGA Championship. His best result was a share of 20th in 2022 but he missed the cut last year.\n\nThe field includes 21 club professionals, 20 qualifiers and Michael Block, who returns after sharing 15th last year at He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... Former McDowell man serving life sentence for murder killed in prison Former McDowell High School counselor charged with sex acts on a student makes court appearance McDowell shortstop Eli Elliott signs to play with Ferrum College McDowell family grateful for help during girl's medical crisis Work begins to renovate McDowell County's Rec Center Man sentenced to prison for second-degree murder in Marion Marion couple charged with child abuse appear in court A heckler tried to derail Trevor Noah's speech at Wake Forest University. He answered her question Alumni Spotlight: Ceara Carmack Couple charged by McDowell Sheriff's Office with theft Burke teen killed in Hildebran crash Man charged with driving vehicle of dead man Marion police officers make arrests for narcotics Inmate charged with malicious conduct MTCC to hold two graduation ceremonies this year\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this While LIV Golf celebrated the news, many were surprised at how few invites LIV received. LIV golfers received 18 invites in 2023.\n\nAnd in a now-deleted tweet, two-time PGA Championship winner Phil Mickelson seemed to suggest that not inviting LIV golfers to participate in golf's major events could backfire. \"What about next year when more great players join (LIV),\" Mickelson tweeted. Implying that keeping LIV golfers out would ultimately backfire on the PGA.\n\nLIV's Brooks Koepka is the reigning PGA Championship winner, and an odds-on favorite to repeat. And no doubt, Jon Rahm, the world No. 5, will make a run. Nonetheless, there's a good chance that LIV, for all its bluster, could get overshadowed, and not just because they might falter as a group, like what happened at this year's Masters.\n\nFirst off, Tiger Woods is set to play. The four-time PGA champion won at this course in 2000. Viewers will tune in to see Tiger more than LIV. Jordan Spieth is looking to complete the career Grand Slam. And despite his performance at the Master's, where he finished +4, Rory McIlroy drew the crowds. And he won the PGA Championship at Valhalla in 2014. Oh yes, and world number 1 Scottie Scheffler is currently resting as he looks to continue his domination. All of these stories have the potential to overshadow any and all LIV-related storylines.\n\nDespite Phil Mickelson's assertion, at least for this year there appears to be enough overall talent, enough talent in the pipeline, enough competing stories, and enough top PGA golfers, that this could potentially become a make-or-break scenario for LIV. If they perform poorly, or merely adequately, as a group, the major's may not need to fear losing sponsors or viewers if they don't invite LIV golfers. The PGA Championship field list is strong, simply put.\n\nCertainly the PGA Championship wants to maintain its reputation for having the world's very best golfers in the tournament. So why then would LIV's Talor Gooch, currently rated No. 644 in the world, get a special exemption to play? Because, as SI's John Schwarb suggests, the PGA is willing to overlook Official World Golf Rankings. True. Since joining LIV Golf in 2022, Gooch has been one of the league's best, even being named LIV Golf's player of the year in 2023. While playing little outside of LIV.\n\nGooch's selection seems to suggest that the PGA are closely monitoring LIV golfer performance, at least individual performance. The Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR) does not recognize LIV events in their rankings methodology. For example, Patrick Reed's streak of 40 consecutive majors starts, going back to 2014, was in danger of ending. But the LIV golfer ultimately received a special exemption to play the PGA Championship. As Kerry Haigh, the managing director of championship for the PGA of America, has stated, \"if players are deserving, hopefully we would invite them,\" even if their OWGR doesn't officially merit an invitation. While fans of LIV Golf are generally pleased that sixteen players got exemptions, the reliance on multiple lists, special invitations, and veiled threats-from both sides-is not helping.", "source": {"uri": "2024-05-349371678", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:12:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:12:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:43:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.aol.com/pga-championship-field-16-liv-174306947.html", "title": "PGA Championship field to include 16 LIV Golf players, including 2023 champ Brooks Koepka", "body": "PGA Championship field to include 16 LIV Golf players, including 2023 champ Brooks KoepkaLorenzo Reyes, USA TODAYMay 8, 2024 at 12:43 PM\n\nThe PGA Championship has already had one of its recent winners come from the LIV Golf ranks. This year, 16 players - including defending 2023 champion Brooks Koepka - will try to make it two in a row for the Saudi-backed tour.\n\nThe 2024 PGA Championship will take place May 16-19 at Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Kentucky and it will be the second time in a row that 16 LIV Golf players are participating in the event. The crop of LIV Golf players also includes other previous champions who won the event when they were members of the PGA Tour.\n\nHere's everything you need to know about the LIV Golf players competing at the 2024 PGA Championship.\n\nWho are the LIV Golf players competing at the 2024 PGA Championship?\n\nHere's the list of the 16 LIV Golf players who will compete in the 2024 PGA Championship, in alphabetical order:\n\nDean Burmester, 34, Stinger GCBryson DeChambeau, 30, Crushers GCTalor Gooch, 32, Smash GCTyrrell Hatton, 32, Legion XIIILucas Herbert, 28, Ripper GCDustin Johnson, 39, 4Aces GCMartin Kaymer, 39, Cleeks GC* (2010)Brooks Koepka, 34, Smash GC* (2018, 2019, 2023)Adrian Meronk, 30, Cleeks GCPhil Mickelson, 53, HyFlyers GC* (2005, 2021)Joaquin Niemann, 25, Torque GCAndy Ogletree, 26, HyFlyers GCDavid Puig, 22, Fireballs GCJon Rahm, 29, Legion XIIIPatrick Reed, 33, 4Aces GCCameron Smith, 30, Ripper GC\n\n*denotes previous PGA Championship title\n\nHow can I watch the PGA Championship?\n\nThe PGA Championship will take place starting Thursday, May 16 and will run through Sunday, May 19. Thursday and Friday's coverage will be available on ESPN and ESPN+, while the morning coverage on Saturday and Sunday will be on ESPN and ESPN+ and the afternoon coverage on Saturday and Sunday will be on CBS and Paramount+.\n\nWhat is the LIV Golf Invitational Series?\n\nThe LIV Golf Invitational Series made its debut in June 2022 after the tour lured some notable players from the PGA Tour such as Phil Mickelson and Dustin Johnson. Others like Brooks Koepka, the winner of the most recent PGA Championship, Bryson DeChambeau and Cameron Smith have since joined. The LIV tour presented a disruption in the dynamics of the sport.\n\nWhy is LIV Golf so controversial?\n\nThe Public Investment Fund (PIF), the sovereign wealth investment fund of Saudi Arabia and one of the largest in the world, has backed and is financing LIV Golf Investments, the parent company of LIV Golf. As the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, Mohammed bin Salman is the head of the PIF. According to a declassified U.S. intelligence report released in February 2021, Salman approved an operation \"to capture or kill\" Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi inside a Saudi consulate in Istanbul on Oct. 2, 2018.\n\nThe Saudi government is accused of other human rights violations and has invested in Western athletic opportunities in an apparent attempt to improve its image, a practice known as \"sportswashing.\"\n\nThis article originally appeared on USA TODAY: PGA Championship 2024 field to include 16 LIV Golf players", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8116026343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:38:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:38:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:38:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/golf-news-golfer-who-matched-tiger-woods-record-gets-invited-to-the-pga-championship-along-with-several-liv-golfers/", "title": "Golfer Who Matched Tiger Woods' Record Gets Invited To The PGA Championship Along With Several LIV Golfers - The SportsRush", "body": "Earlier this year, golf pro Kazuma Kobori gained limelight when he matched golf legend Tiger Woods' record of winning three professional titles in his first 10 starts on the PGA Tour of Australasia. Now, the 22-year-old Kiwi has a chance to share the stage with the legendary American golfer at the 2024 PGA Championship. He has joined the PGA of America's late invitee list along with two LIV Golfers - Talor Gooch and David Puig.\n\nKobori was rewarded with the Challenger PGA Tour of Australasia Order of Merit accolade last season. Interestingly, his predecessor David Micheluzzi, also received a special invite to last year's second major.\n\nKobori received a special invitation for his sensational triumphs on the PGA Tour of Australasia. The golfer was informed about his invite on early Tuesday morning. If the PGA of America had not sent a special invite to the World No. 432 for the Valhalla competition, he would make his major debut at the 2024 Open Championship. However, it seems like Christmas has come early for the 22-year-old Kiwi golfer.\n\nIt will be intriguing to see what the young gun has under his sleeves when he faces the best golfers at the 2024 PGA Championship next week.\n\nBefore the PGA of America announced the official field list for the 106th edition of the PGA Championship, eight LIV golfers were already eligible to compete at the major which included Brooks Koepka, Tyrrell Hatton, Bryson DeChambeau, Dustin Johnson, Phil Mickelson, Martin Kaymer, Cameron Smith, and Jon Rahm. Following that, in March 2024, Joaquin Niemann also ended up receiving a special invite for the major.\n\nBefore Tuesday, only nine LIV Golfers were set to play at Valhalla Golf Course next week. However, after the official field was announced, the number of players from the Saudi-backed league increased to 16.\n\nAlthough the PGA of America announced the field on Tuesday, the League's 2023 Individual Champion Talor Gooch leaked the information out of excitement on his X handle. Now, as per the updated field, Lucas Herbert, Dean Burmester, Adrian Meronk, David Puig, Andy Ogletree, and Patrick Reed will also be joining Gooch in the upcoming major championship.\n\nInterestingly, the number of LIV golfers at the PGA Championship is three times more than the ones who participated at the 2024 Masters. Last year, Brooks Koepka became the first LIV golfer to win a major after he won the PGA Championship title last year. Woods in 2000 and McIlroy in 2014 in his most recent major triumph.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 major winners, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners.\n\nTwo vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe lineup includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title last month, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings.\n\nScheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby.\n\nDefending champion Brooks Koepka of the United States is among 16 players from the LIV Golf League who will compete in the year's second major tournament.\n\nOther LIV players from the world's top 100 include fifth-ranked Jon Rahm, England's 17th-ranked Tyrrell Hatton, Australia's Cameron Smith and Lucas Herbert, Poland's Adrian Meronk, Chile's Joaquin Niemann and American Patrick Reed.\n\nOther major winners from LIV include Bryson DeChambeau, Phil Mickelson, Dustin Johnson and Martin Kaymer.\n\nAmerican Talor Gooch, last year's LIV season champion, was invited into his fifth consecutive PGA Championship. Championship at Valhalla.\n\nWoods, a 15-time major winner, has struggled to walk four rounds in tournaments since suffering severe leg injuries in a 2021 car crash but finished 60th in last month's Masters and says he hopes to play once a month through the US and British Opens.\n\nWoods, ranked 801, has accepted a special invitation to next month's US Open.\n\nHe withdrew after three rounds in 2022 in his most recent PGA Championship start, skipping last year after ankle surgery.\n\nWoods and four-time major winner Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland have each won PGA Championship titles at Valhalla -- Woods in 2000 and McIlroy in 2014 in his most recent major triumph.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 major winners, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners.\n\nTwo vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe lineup includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title last month, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings.\n\nScheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby.\n\nDefending champion Brooks Koepka of the United States is among 16 players from the LIV Golf League who will compete in the year's second major tournament.\n\nOther LIV players from the world's top 100 include fifth-ranked Jon Rahm, England's 17th-ranked Tyrrell Hatton, Australia's Cameron Smith and Lucas Herbert, Poland's Adrian Meronk, Chile's Joaquin Niemann and American Patrick Reed.\n\nOther major winners from LIV include Bryson DeChambeau, Phil Mickelson, Dustin Johnson and Martin Kaymer.\n\nAmerican Talor Gooch, last year's LIV season champion, was invited into his fifth consecutive PGA Championship. {"uri": "8116764733", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "06:12:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T06:12:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:12:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/golf/tiger-woods-and-world-s-top-100-named-in-pga-championship-field", "title": "Tiger Woods and world's top 100 named in PGA Championship field", "body": "WASHINGTON - Tiger Woods and the world's 103 top-ranked golfers were among those named on May 7 as the field was announced for next week's 106th PGA Championship at Valhalla.\n\nWoods, a 15-time Major winner, has struggled to walk four rounds in tournaments since suffering severe leg injuries in a 2021 car crash but finished 60th in the Masters in April.\n\nThe American great, ranked 801st, hopes to play once a month through the US and British Opens - he has already accepted a special invitation into the US Open in June.\n\nThe 48-year-old withdrew after three rounds in 2022 in his most recent PGA Championship start, and he skipped 2023 after ankle surgery. He has won this Major four times in his storied career.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 Major champions, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners.\n\nTwo vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe line-up includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title in April, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings.\n\nScheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event - the Wells Fargo Championship - to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby.\n\nDefending champion Brooks Koepka of the United States is among 16 players from the LIV Golf League who will compete in the year's second Major.\n\nOther LIV players from the world's top 100 include fifth-ranked Jon Rahm, England's 17th-ranked Tyrrell Hatton, Australia's Cameron Smith and Lucas Herbert, Poland's Adrian Meronk, Chile's Joaquin Niemann and American Patrick Reed.\n\nOther Major winners from LIV include Bryson DeChambeau, Phil Mickelson, Dustin Johnson and Martin Kaymer.\n\nAmerican Talor Gooch, last season's LIV season champion, was invited into his fifth consecutive PGA Championship. His best result was a share of 20th in 2022 but he missed the cut in 2023.\n\nLouis Oosthuizen declined a special invitation due to an undisclosed personal commitment.\n\nNotable names who did not receive invitations include former Masters champion Sergio Garcia along with Abraham Ancer and Carlos Ortiz.\n\nGarcia has fallen to 714th in the rankings with a lone top-10 in an OWGR event - a T5 at last season's International Series Oman - since signing with LIV and giving up his DP World Tour membership.\n\nThe field includes 21 club professionals, 20 qualifiers and Michael Block, who returns after sharing 15th in 2023 at Oak Hill. Should a golfer who is already exempt emerge victorious, the PGA of America will go to the alternate list.\n\nKoepka, ranked 37th in the world, recorded his fifth career major last year by winning the PGA Championship at Oak Hill Country Club. He also won the tournament in 2018 and 2019.\n\nPast winners Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy and P\u00e1draig Harrington are also among a decorated field as are World No 1 Scottie Scheffler and Irish major winner Shane Lowry.\n\nWoods, a 15-time major champion, won the PGA Championship in 1999, 2000, 2006 and 2007, while world No 2 McIlroy emerged victorious in 2012 and 2014. Harrington claimed the Wanamaker trophy in 2008.\n\nScheffler, a runner-up last year at this tournament, and the top 103 players in the Official World Golf Ranking will test their mettle at Valhalla.\n\nIn addition to Koepka, LIV Golf supplies 15 other players in the field, the same number as last year and three more than at The masters.\n\nThat list includes World No 5 Jon Rahm of Spain, Tyrrell Hatton (17) of England, Cameron Smith (56) of Australia, Pole Adrian Meronk (63), Australian Lucas Herbert (89) Chile's Joaquin Niemann (91) and Patrick Reed (92).\n\nTwo-time winner Phil Mickelson, Bryson de Chambeau, Martin Kaymer and Dustin Johnson are in due to past major wins while Dean Burmester, David Puig, Talor Gooch and Andy Ogletree received special invitations.\n\nFull He was not invited to the Masters in April and was denied access to the US Open last year on a technicality.\n\nThe American picked up a total of $39.5m from the 2023 LIV Golf individual competition, including a bonus of $18m for topping the solo ranks at the end of the season.\n\nHe will be joined from the Saudi Arabia-backed breakaway league by defending US PGA champion Brooks Koepka, high-flying South American Joaquin Niemann and 22-year-old Spaniard David Puig.\n\nKoepka picked up $18.3m last year on the LIV Golf tour and won the last event before the US PGA Championship this year, in Singapore last week.\n\nLIV Golf chief Greg Norman said: \"The only influence is the success of LIV, our players, our penetration/acceptance and our platform. {"uri": "8116327648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:21:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:21:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:20:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/sports/professional/pga/golf-pga-championship-liv-tour-tiger-woods-reed-valhalla-louisville/article_46d61643-38b9-5c4f-88c3-0d4b6d88a016.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Sparta gets a new boutique, while downtown La Crosse will see a new cafe Steve Cahalan: NOM Sips & Eats cafe to open in downtown La Crosse Amtrak adds second train between Twin Cities, Chicago; Borealis service will stop in La Crosse, Tomah, Winona Toad's Cove ready to reopen as Centerville's only convenience store 1 year after devastating fire Steve Cahalan: Burlington Store to open in October in Onalaska DOJ: Mount Horeb shooter brought pellet gun to school La Crosse orders City Brewery to stop the smells; daily fines begin Monday Onalaska teen faces charges for uploading child pornography Mount Horeb shooting: Students 'saw something' as teen approached school, notified staff Joe Gow's teaching position at issue as UW-La Crosse Faculty Senate to hear unethical conduct allegations Extra Effort: Luther High student overcomes school difficulties on her way to education career Melrose man faces charges of stalking and vandalism in jealous rage Onalaska man faces 60 years for alleged sexual assault of girls Warrant issued for La Crosse man accused of reckless endangerment UW-Madison professor injured at protest: 'They specifically targeted me'\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "lacrossetribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "La Crosse Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_j_phillip@lacrossetribune.com", "name": "David J. Koepka topped the PGA Championship field at Oak Hill Country Club a year ago for his fifth major victory. However, he is just 12-1 to win in the 2024 PGA Championship odds because of the fierce competition he faces. Scottie Scheffler was a runner-up at last year's PGA Championship, but he is the 4-1 favorite in the 2024 PGA Championship field coming off a victory at the Masters. Jon Rahm is next among the 2024 PGA Championship golfers at 10-1, and Rory McIlroy, who is still looking for his first win of the season, is 12-1.\n\nBefore locking in any 2024 PGA Championship picks of your own, entering PGA DFS lineups on sites like DraftKings or FanDuel, or finalizing PGA Championship props and PGA Championship Pick Six entries, be sure to see the 2024 PGA Championship golf predictions and projected leaderboard from the proven computer model at SportsLine.\n\nOur proprietary model, built by DFS pro Mike McClure, has been red-hot since the PGA Tour resumed in June of 2020. In fact, the model is up almost $10,000 on its best bets since the restart, nailing tournament after tournament.\n\nMcClure's model correctly predicted Scottie Scheffler would finish on top of the leaderboard at the 2024 Masters, the Arnold Palmer Invitational, and The Players Championship this season. McClure also included Hideki Matsuyama in his best bets to win the 2024 Genesis Invitational. That bet hit at +9000, and for the entire tournament, McClure's best bets returned nearly $1,000.\n\nThe model also predicted Jon Rahm would be victorious at the 2023 Sentry Tournament of Champions and The American Express. At the 2023 Masters, the model was all over Rahm's second career major victory heading into the weekend. Rahm was two strokes off the lead heading into the third round, but the model still projected him as the winner. It was the second straight Masters win for the model, which also nailed Scheffler winning in 2022.\n\nIn addition, McClure's best bets included Nick Taylor (70-1) winning the 2023 RBC Canadian Open, Jason Day (17-1) winning outright at the 2023 AT&T Byron Nelson, and Rickie Fowler (14-1) finishing on top of the leaderboard at the 2023 Rocket Mortgage Classic.\n\nThis same model has also nailed a whopping 11 majors entering the weekend and hit the Masters three straight years. Anyone who has followed it has seen massive returns.\n\nNow with the PGA Championship 2024 field taking shape, SportsLine simulated the tournament 10,000 times, and the results were surprising. Head to SportsLine now to see the projected leaderboard.\n\nTop 2024 PGA Championship predictions\n\nOne major surprise the model is calling for at the 2024 PGA Championship: Brooks Koepka, a three-time PGA champion and one of the favorites, stumbles and doesn't even crack the top 10. Koepka has five major tournament wins on his resume and a reputation for elevating his level of play in big events. However, his last two major starts haven't gone well as he was 45th at the Masters, which followed a 64th-place finish at last year's Open Championship. He's failed to shoot par in each of his last seven rounds at major tournaments.\n\nAfter notching three tournament wins in 2023, including last year's PGA Championship, it has been tough sledding for Koepka in 2024. He has no victories, or even top-fives, and across his six starts, he has three times as many finishes outside the top 25 (three) as he has inside the top 10 (one). He played Valhalla at the 2014 PGA Championship and finished in a tie for 15th place, but that placement ranks just eighth out of his 11 career PGA Championship starts.\n\nAnother surprise: Will Zalatoris, a 25-1 longshot, makes a strong run at the title. He's a target for anyone looking for a huge payday. The San Francisco native is rebounding this season after a back injury derailed his 2023 campaign and has three top-10 finishes heading into the month of May. He finished second at the Genesis invitational, fourth at the Arnold Palmer Invitational, and was impressive in his ninth-place finish at the Masters earlier this month.\n\nZalatoris has proven in the past he can turn his game up at major events and finished in the top 10 in the PGA Championship twice in his career, including a second-place finish in 2022. He ranks ninth on the PGA Tour in strokes gained: approach to green (0.694) which could give him an advantage at Valhalla for the 2024 PGA Championship. {"uri": "8116313100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:06:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:06:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:05:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/professional/pga/golf-pga-championship-liv-tour-tiger-woods-reed-valhalla-louisville/article_acb894de-86cf-5b2b-8e23-12b5eaa31f8b.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... Spokesman says second David Schultz autopsy to proceed without body, calls out Facebook group 7 arrested in 2-day prostitution operation in Sioux City Tacos La Juanita plans second Sioux City location; fifth overall Hinton woman boarded freight train rather than drive home drunk DEAR ABBY: Bitter son won't allow mom to find happiness 64-year-old driver dies in South Sioux City crash North Sioux City propane explosion kills three in fire Woodbury County Court Report for April 30, 2024 Meet the ushers who help Sioux City's Orpheum Theatre move Five Questions with ... Sarah Kragthorpe, owner of Jitters, on moving the coffee shop Iowa Landscaping Company: 'Anything anybody can dream of, we can pretty much do.' Suspended Sioux City inclusion liaison accuses human rights director of harassment, defamation Names released in deadly North Sioux City fire Bill Murray makes lasting impression while in Omaha for Berkshire Hathaway meeting Sioux City cultural inclusion liaison settles lawsuit with USD\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I {"uri": "8116308107", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:02:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:02:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/sports/professional/pga/golf-pga-championship-liv-tour-tiger-woods-reed-valhalla-louisville/article_d2eeb362-be79-5578-b230-3c72b47d08a9.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... UPDATE WITH PHOTO: Police arrest naked man for blocking road in Waterloo UPDATE: Motorcyclist injured in Wednesday Cedar Falls crash has died Two arrested in Cedar Falls after police found bugs, feces in mobile home Medo's takes the place of Restoran Bosna in Waterloo with grand opening Friday Police investigating person with gunshot wound UPDATE: Second person charged in 2021 Traer homicide Summit CEO says company does not intend to comply with Bremer County's ordinance College Men's Basketball: Coe College guard commits to UNI as grad transfer Second David Schultz autopsy to proceed without body, spokesman calls out Facebook group New Iowa law regulates traffic cameras, which generated $1.16 million for Waterloo in 2023 Iowa woman boarded freight train rather than drive home drunk High School Track & Field: Jesup star wants to be \"Jack of All Trades\" Iowa homeowners age 65 and up are eligible for state tax exemption Summer hours, fees set at The Falls Aquatic Center in Cedar Falls Officer manager at Cedar Falls business sentenced to prison for wire fraud\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "wcfcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Waterloo Cedar Falls Courier"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_j_phillip@wcfcourier.com", "name": "David J. and world's top 100 named in PGA Championship field", "body": "Tiger Woods and the world's 103 top-ranked golfers were among those named Tuesday as the field was announced for next week's 106th PGA Championship at Valhalla.\n\nWoods, a 15-time major winner, has struggled to walk four rounds in tournaments since suffering severe leg injuries in a 2021 car crash but finished 60th in last month's Masters and says he hopes to play once a month through the US and British Opens.\n\nWoods, ranked 801, has accepted a special invitation into next month's US Open.\n\nHe withdrew after three rounds in 2022 in his most recent PGA Championship start, skipping last year after ankle surgery.\n\nWoods and four-time major winner Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland have each won PGA Championship titles at Valhalla -- Woods in 2000 and McIlroy in 2014 in his most recent major triumph.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 major winners, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners.\n\nTwo vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe lineup includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title last month, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings.\n\nMore from this section No letup yet for flood-battered southern Brazil Travis Kelce arrives at Kentucky Derby 2024 BBC The Responder's Martin Freeman speaks out on Scouse accent reaction: 'Got away with it!'\n\nScheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby.\n\nDefending champion Brooks Koepka of the United States is among 16 players from the LIV Golf League who will compete in the year's second major tournament.\n\nOther LIV players from the world's top 100 include fifth-ranked Jon Rahm, England's 17th-ranked Tyrrell Hatton, Australia's Cameron Smith and Lucas Herbert, Poland's Adrian Meronk, Chile's Joaquin Niemann and American Patrick Reed.\n\nOther major winners from LIV include Bryson DeChambeau, Phil Mickelson, Dustin Johnson and Martin Kaymer.\n\nAmerican Talor Gooch, last year's LIV season champion, was invited into his fifth consecutive PGA Championship. His best result was a share of 20th in 2022 but he missed the cut last year.\n\nThe field includes 21 club professionals, 20 qualifiers and Michael Block, who returns after sharing 15th last year at What to know.", "body": "The second of golf's four major championships gets underway next week as the PGA Championship moves to Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Kentucky. This is the fourth time the tournament will be played at Valhalla, following hosting duties in 1996, 2000 and 2014.\n\nThe last time the event was held at Valhalla, Rory McIlroy held off Phil Mickelson by one stroke and won his second Wanamaker Trophy. Mcllroy hasn't won a major championship since.\n\nScottie Scheffler, who is ranked No. 1 in the world and coming off his second victory at the Masters, is the overwhelming favorite to win at a tournament he finished in a tie for second place last year, and defending champion Brooks Koepka is attempting to become the fourth golfer to win at least four PGA Championship titles. (Walter Hagen and Jack Nicholas 5; Tiger Woods, 4)\n\nHere's everything you need to know about the 2024 PGA Championship:\n\nThe PGA Championship will take place Thursday, May 16 through Sunday, May 19.\n\nValhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Kentucky will be the host of this year's PGA Championship.\n\nThe purse for the PGA Championship is $17.5 million, with the winner set to receive $3.15 million.\n\nAlternate telecasts can be seen on ESPN2 from 11 a.m.-3 p.m. on May 16-17, and ESPN+ from 9 a.m.-1 p.m. on May 18-19.\n\nViewers can stream the PGA Championship on ESPN app and CBS Sports Live.\n\nBrooks Koepka won his third PGA Championship and his fifth major championship at the Oak Hill Country Club in Pittsford, New York.\n\nKoepka was the first player from LIV Golf to win a major and shot a 3-under 67 in the final round for a two-shot victory over Viktor Hovland and Scottie Scheffler.\n\nThe PGA Championship field will consist of 156 players, including 99 of the 100 highest-ranked players in the world.\n\nThe PGA invited seven players from the Saudi-backed LIV Golf, and the field will consist of 16 players from that tour.\n\nWoods is on the current field list and will attempt to win his fifth PGA Championship. His last title came in 2007. He also won in 1999, 2000 and 2006.\n\nOdds courtesy of BetMGM\n\nGannett may earn revenue from sports betting operators for audience referrals to betting services. "Tiger and world's top 100 named in PGA Championship field", "body": "Tiger Woods and the world's 103 top-ranked golfers were among those named Tuesday as the field was announced for next week's 106th PGA Championship at Valhalla.\n\nWoods, a 15-time major winner, has struggled to walk four rounds in tournaments since suffering severe leg injuries in a 2021 car crash but finished 60th in last month's Masters and says he hopes to play once a month through the US and British Opens.\n\nWoods, ranked 801, has accepted a special invitation into next month's US Open.\n\nHe withdrew after three rounds in 2022 in his most recent PGA Championship start, skipping last year after ankle surgery.\n\nWoods and four-time major winner Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland have each won PGA Championship titles at Valhalla -- Woods in 2000 and McIlroy in 2014 in his most recent major triumph.\n\nThe PGA field includes 33 major winners, 16 of them former PGA Championship winners.\n\nTwo vacancies remain in the field of 156, awaiting winners of this week's PGA Tour events if they are not already qualified for the showdown at Louisville, Kentucky.\n\nThe lineup includes top-ranked Scottie Scheffler, who won his second Masters title last month, and the rest of the top 103 players in the official world golf rankings.\n\nScheffler is skipping this week's PGA Tour signature event to be with wife Meredith as she prepares to have a baby.\n\nDefending champion Brooks Koepka of the United States is among 16 players from the LIV Golf League who will compete in the year's second major tournament.\n\nOther LIV players from the world's top 100 include fifth-ranked Jon Rahm, England's 17th-ranked Tyrrell Hatton, Australia's Cameron Smith and Lucas Herbert, Poland's Adrian Meronk, Chile's Joaquin Niemann and American Patrick Reed.\n\nOther major winners from LIV include Bryson DeChambeau, Phil Mickelson, Dustin Johnson and Martin Kaymer.\n\nAmerican Talor Gooch, last year's LIV season champion, was invited into his fifth consecutive PGA Championship. His best result was a share of 20th in 2022 but he missed the cut last year.\n\nThe field includes 21 club professionals, 20 qualifiers and Michael Block, who returns after sharing 15th last year at This year will mark the golf course's fourth time hosting the major.\n\nBrooks Koepka will also be there looking to defend his title after winning the major for the third time at Oak Hill last year.\n\nLIV GOLF'S PHIL MICKELSON SENDS STRONG WARNING ABOUT THE FUTURE OF GOLF IN SINCE-DELETED SOCIAL MEDIA POST\n\nIn addition to Koepka, LIV Golf will be represented by 16 players this year, down from last year's 18 who entered the field.\n\nThe concern surrounding LIV Golf players qualifying for major championships reached a boiling point for Phil Mickelson this week. He sent a stark warning about the future of golf in a since-deleted post on X.\n\n\"Maybe some LIV players won't be missed. But what if NONE of the LIV players played? Would they be missed? What about next year when more great players join? Or the following year? At some point they will care and will have to answer to sponsors and television,\" Mickelson wrote, via The Associated Press.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nBut the PGA Championship, at least for this year, will maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors.\n\nSeven of the LIV players invited means this year's field will have the entire top 100 in the Others like Brooks Koepka, the winner of the most recent PGA Championship, Bryson DeChambeau and Cameron Smith have since joined. The LIV tour presented a disruption in the dynamics of the sport.\n\nThe Public Investment Fund (PIF), the sovereign wealth investment fund of Saudi Arabia and one of the largest in the world, has backed and is financing LIV Golf Investments, the parent company of LIV Golf. As the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, Mohammed bin Salman is the head of the PIF. PGA Championship bound golfer's record explored", "body": "Talor Gooch is one of the most talked about golfers around the world. A one-time winner on the PGA Tour, Gooch made heads turn when he joined Saudi-backed LIV Golf in 2022. Since then, the 32-year-old seems to have made progress in his professional career.\n\nOn the LIV Golf Tour, Talor Gooch has managed to amass three individual victories. His first victory came on April 23, 2023, when he beat Anirban Lahiri to win LIV Golf Adelaide by a margin of three strokes. This victory was the beginning of a special year for Gooch.\n\nImmediately after his victory down under, Gooch participated in LIV Golf Singapore on April 30, 2023. Like Adelaide, Singapore also yielded fruitful results for the 32-year-old golfer as he beat Sergio Garcia in the playoffs to win the competition.\n\nFollowing his victory in Singapore, Talor Gooch had to wait almost a month before securing his third title on the LIV Golf Tour. Gooch beat Bryson DeChambeau by one stroke to win LIV Golf Andalucia.\n\nTalor Gooch received an invitation to play at the upcoming PGA Championship\n\nA major, the upcoming PGA Championship is one of the most important events on the PGA Tour. Set to take place from May 16 to May 19 at the Valhalla Golf Course, the PGA Championship will feature some big names from the tour, making the event a must-watch.\n\nHowever, among all the big names set to feature at the PGA Championship, a surprising name is Talor Gooch, who has received an invitation to play at the PGA Championship. Given the fact that he did not do anything to qualify for the event, this invitation shocked many fans and pundits alike.\n\nRegardless, the 32-year-old decided to grab this opportunity with both hands. {"uri": "2024-05-348701186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "08:27:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T08:27:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T07:14:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://firstsportz.com/tiger-woods-named-in-playing-field-for-pga-championship/", "title": "15x major champion Tiger Woods named in playing field for 2024 PGA Championship", "body": "Tiger Woods' last appearance at the PGA Championship came in 2022 which saw him withdraw from the event due to an injury in the third round.\n\nThe PGA Championship on Tuesday released the list of the playing field for the second major of the year. The tournament scheduled to take place from May 16th at the Valhalla course, will feature Tiger Woods and the world's top 100 players.\n\nWoods, the 15-time major champion, will be making his fourth start at the Valhalla. His playoff win at this course in 2000 saw him defend his PGA Championship. This was his third straight major win which eventually saw him complete the \"Tiger Slam\" after he won the Masters in 2001.\n\nHis previous appearance at this site was one to forget though. In 2014, Woods shot successive rounds of 74 while playing with a some pain in the back and ended up missing the cut.\n\nThe news of Tiger Woods playing in this major event comes a few days after he received a special exemption from the USGA to play in the U.S. Open at Pinehurst in June. Woods had failed to qualify for the U.S. Open due to his OWGR rankings.\n\nThe exemption that he received from winning the 2019 Masters had also expired. This left him with no other possible ways to appear in the third major of the year. With the Open Championship allowing the past champions to play till the age of 55, the 48-year-old golfer is now on pace to play in all four majors of the year.\n\nThis year the PGA Championship field boasts arguably the strongest field with all of the top 100 players in the World Rankings set to tee off next week. A total of 156 players have been named for this tournament, meaning Brooks Koepka, the defending champion, will have to bring out his A game if he wants to claim his sixth major next week.\n\nBrooks Koepka aiming to repeat back-to-back wins at the PGA Championship\n\nWith the 106th PGA Championship on the horizon, five-time major champion Brooks Koepka is eyeing history. He is aiming to repeat back-to-back wins at the PGA Championship this year as he hopes to defend his crown which he won last year at Oak Hill.\n\nKoepka's win in May last year him become the first LIV Golf star to claim victory at a PGA Tour event. The four-time LIV Golf winner thinks it would be \"cool\" if he went back-to-back just like he did it if before in the years 2018 and 2019.\n\nIn 2018, Koepka claimed his second straight U.S. Open title and won the PGA Championship as well. He went on to retain the PGA Championship crown in 2019 at Bethpage and thus went back-to-back in two different major championships.\n\nIf Koepka is successful next week, he will become just the second golfer after Tiger Woods to claim successive wins at the PGA Championships on two separate occasions. Woods first won the title in 1999 and defended it successfully in 2000. He later went on to win this event in 2006 and 2007. With momentum on his side following the win in Singapore, it will be interesting to see how Koepka performs.\n\nIn case you missed it:", "source": {"uri": "firstsportz.com", "dataType": "news",
