{"uri": "2024-05-347963453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:56:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:56:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:07:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/analysis-brooks-koepka-has-a-big-game-he-doesnt-need-a-lot-of-words/article_e186ec50-68ca-58ff-bd40-d33ae61f13a3.html", "title": "Analysis: Brooks Koepka has a big game. He doesn't need a lot of words", "body": "Brooks Koepka leaves the bluster to everyone else at LIV Golf. He cares about only his golf, especially when it's not going the way he wants.\n\nHe was burning inside a year ago when he played not to lose in the final round of the Masters and watched his two-shot lead turn into a four-shot loss. He vowed not to let that happen again, and he delivered a month later by claiming his fifth major title at the PGA Championship.\n\nKoepka found more motivation in failure already this year. That he was an afterthought in five LIV Golf events wasn't nearly as irritating as being a no-show at Augusta National. He failed to break par in any round and beat only 10 players who made the cut.\n\nHe was asked in Singapore how is game was trending.\n\n\"Clearly not very good, with Augusta the way that went,\" Koepka said, living up to his reputation of cutting to the chase. \"I kind of felt like I wasted all the time from December until then. Just keep grinding away, keep doing the work, and hopefully something will turn around.\"\n\nAnd it did.\n\nHe made 17 birdies over three rounds in Singapore, was never seriously challenged on the final day and won by two shots. He referred to the Masters as a wake-up call.\n\nIt might be that way for others, too, especially with the PGA Championship at Valhalla next on the docket.\n\nKoepka is the first player to win four LIV Golf titles.\n\nThat doesn't make him the betting favorite at the PGA Championship. Scottie Scheffler has won four times in the last two months against far stronger fields (and over 72 holes) -- in two signature events, The Players Championship and the Masters.\n\nThe search is for who can stop him, and a couple of candidates have emerged in recent weeks as Scheffler waits at home in Dallas for the birth of his first child.\n\nRory McIlroy won in New Orleans, albeit a team event with Shane Lowry, and restored some of the fun in golf that had been sorely missing. He won the last time the PGA Championship was at Valhalla, a wild finish in the dark with McIlroy joining the group ahead -- Phil Mickelson and Rickie Fowler, both still with hopes of winning -- in an effort to finish.\n\nLudvig Aberg is the best futures bet on challenging Scheffler. He's a month away from completing one year as a pro and already is No. 6 in the world ranking with two wins and a Ryder Cup celebration. In his first major, he was runner-up to Scheffler at the Masters.\n\nBut there's something fascinating about Koepka, particularly in the majors, and whenever he seems to have a chip on his shoulder that he puts there himself.\n\nHe once said majors were the easiest to win because they effectively had the smallest fields by process of elimination. Koepka figured he was flat-out better than half of the 156-man field and half of those guys would be off their game. Then he began to factor in how can they handle the pressure. By his math, it was only a few guys left to beat.\n\nSimple.\n\nAnd then he won another major.\n\nTwo days after he made those comments, Koepka opened with 63-65 at Bethpage Black in the 2019 PGA Championship to set a major championship record for 36 holes. He set PGA Championship records for largest 36- and 54-hole leads.\n\nThe back nine on Sunday wasn't pretty when he made four straight bogeys and fans on Long Island began cheering for more. Unfazed, Koepka closed it out for a two-shot victory.\n\n\"It's New York. What do you expect when you're half-choking it away?\" Koepka said.\n\nNo bull. No bluster.\n\nHe doesn't always deliver. There was the shade he threw Dustin Johnson's way the following year at Harding Park when Koepka was trying to become the first player to win three straight PGA Championship titles in stroke play.\n\nHe was two shots behind Johnson after 54 holes and said: \"When I've been in this position before, I've capitalized. He's only won one. I'm playing good. I don't know, we'll see.\" Koepka didn't make a birdie until the 12th hole, shot 74 and tied for 29th.\n\nHe failed to take down 50-year-old Mickelson at Kiawah Island. He lost a 54-hole lead to Jon Rahm at the Masters last year.\n\nBut he's always there.\n\nThere's still a loose notion that LIV Golf's format, schedule and guaranteed riches don't prepare its players for the majors. The results don't bear that out -- three LIV players finished in the top 10 at the Masters this year and last, three in the PGA Championship last year, two in the U.S. Open.\n\nAnd it should never apply to Koepka. His record in the majors, when he is healthy, is daunting.\n\n\"I think the big thing that kind of separates me is my ability to lock in and go someplace where I think a lot of guys can't go,\" he said in Singapore.\n\nThat ability allowed him to win one U.S. Open by tying the record score to par (16 under) at Erin Hills, and win the next year with a score over par at Shinnecock Hills. He also won back-to-back in the PGA Championship.\n\n\"Hopefully looking to do it again,\" he said. \"I don't know if it's ever been done, but it would be kind of a cool thing.\"\n\nWinning back to back in the majors on three occasions has been done. Tiger Woods did it four times -- the Masters (2001-02), the PGA Championship (1999-2000 and 2006-07) and the British Open (2005-06). Just not at the U.S. Open.\n\nWoods never said it was easy. It never is. Koepka likes it that way.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": The 2024 PGA Championship heads to Valhalla Golf Course in Louisville, Kentucky, this May for the 106th edition of the storied tournament.\n\nScotie Scheffler has topped the PGA Championship odds board for many months and leads the field following his 2024 Masters win.\n\nWith the major tournaments drawing the eye of golf bettors, oddsmakers cook up multiple markets to wager on. Golf fans in Canada can watch or stream the 2021 PGA Championship on TSN.\n\nWanamaker Trophy\n\nThe winner of the PGA Championship is awarded the Wanamaker Trophy. This trophy is named after American businessman Rodman Wanamaker, one of the original founders of the PGA who provided the prize money and trophies for the first PGA Championship in 1916. The winner of the tournament must return the Wanamaker Trophy before the next year's event but is given a smaller replica of the award.\n\nHow to bet on golf\n\nMajor tournaments like the PGA Championship bring out plenty of new bettors looking to wager on golf for the first time. {"uri": "8115863107", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:48:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:48:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:42:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13392095/Analysis-Brooks-Koepka-big-game-He-doesnt-need-lot-words.html", "title": "Analysis: Brooks Koepka has a big game. He doesn't need a lot of words", "body": "Brooks Koepka leaves the bluster to everyone else at LIV Golf. He cares about only his golf, especially when it's not going the way he wants.\n\nHe was burning inside a year ago when he played not to lose in the final round of the Masters and watched his two-shot lead turn into a four-shot loss. He vowed not to let that happen again, and he delivered a month later by claiming his fifth major title at the PGA Championship.\n\nKoepka found more motivation in failure already this year. That he was an afterthought in five LIV Golf events wasn't nearly as irritating as being a no-show at Augusta National. He failed to break par in any round and beat only 10 players who made the cut.\n\nHe was asked in Singapore how is game was trending.\n\n\"Clearly not very good, with Augusta the way that went,\" Koepka said, living up to his reputation of cutting to the chase. \"I kind of felt like I wasted all the time from December until then. Just keep grinding away, keep doing the work, and hopefully something will turn around.\"\n\nAnd it did.\n\nIndividual champion captain Brooks Koepka, of Smash GC, poses with the trophy after the final round of LIV Golf Singapore at Sentosa Golf Club, Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Sentosa, Singapore. (Jon Ferrey/LIV Golf via AP)\n\nHe made 17 birdies over three rounds in Singapore, was never seriously challenged on the final day and won by two shots. He referred to the Masters as a wake-up call.\n\nIt might be that way for others, too, especially with the PGA Championship at Valhalla next on the docket.\n\nKoepka is the first player to win four LIV Golf titles.\n\nThat doesn't make him the betting favorite at the PGA Championship. Scottie Scheffler has won four times in the last two months against far stronger fields (and over 72 holes) - in two signature events, The Players Championship and the Masters.\n\nThe search is for who can stop him, and a couple of candidates have emerged in recent weeks as Scheffler waits at home in Dallas for the birth of his first child.\n\nRory McIlroy won in New Orleans, albeit a team event with Shane Lowry, and restored some of the fun in golf that had been sorely missing. He won the last time the PGA Championship was at Valhalla, a wild finish in the dark with McIlroy joining the group ahead - Phil Mickelson and Rickie Fowler, both still with hopes of winning - in an effort to finish.\n\nLudvig Aberg is the best futures bet on challenging Scheffler. He's a month away from completing one year as a pro and already is No. 6 in the world ranking with two wins and a Ryder Cup celebration. In his first major, he was runner-up to Scheffler at the Masters.\n\nBut there's something fascinating about Koepka, particularly in the majors, and whenever he seems to have a chip on his shoulder that he puts there himself.\n\nHe once said majors were the easiest to win because they effectively had the smallest fields by process of elimination. Koepka figured he was flat-out better than half of the 156-man field and half of those guys would be off their game. Then he began to factor in how can they handle the pressure. By his math, it was only a few guys left to beat.\n\nSimple.\n\nAnd then he won another major.\n\nTwo days after he made those comments, Koepka opened with 63-65 at Bethpage Black in the 2019 PGA Championship to set a major championship record for 36 holes. He set PGA Championship records for largest 36- and 54-hole leads.\n\nThe back nine on Sunday wasn't pretty when he made four straight bogeys and fans on Long Island began cheering for more. Unfazed, Koepka closed it out for a two-shot victory.\n\n\"It's New York. What do you expect when you're half-choking it away?\" Koepka said.\n\nNo bull. No bluster.\n\nHe doesn't always deliver. There was the shade he threw Dustin Johnson's way the following year at Harding Park when Koepka was trying to become the first player to win three straight PGA Championship titles in stroke play.\n\nHe was two shots behind Johnson after 54 holes and said: \"When I\u00b4ve been in this position before, I\u00b4ve capitalized. He\u00b4s only won one. I\u00b4m playing good. I don\u00b4t know, we\u00b4ll see.\" Koepka didn't make a birdie until the 12th hole, shot 74 and tied for 29th.\n\nHe failed to take down 50-year-old Mickelson at Kiawah Island. He lost a 54-hole lead to Jon Rahm at the Masters last year.\n\nBut he's always there.\n\nThere's still a loose notion that LIV Golf's format, schedule and guaranteed riches don't prepare its players for the majors. The results don't bear that out - three LIV players finished in the top 10 at the Masters this year and last, three in the PGA Championship last year, two in the U.S. Open.\n\nAnd it should never apply to Koepka. His record in the majors, when he is healthy, is daunting.\n\n\"I think the big thing that kind of separates me is my ability to lock in and go someplace where I think a lot of guys can\u00b4t go,\" he said in Singapore.\n\nThat ability allowed him to win one U.S. Open by tying the record score to par (16 under) at Erin Hills, and win the next year with a score over par at Shinnecock Hills. He also won back-to-back in the PGA Championship.\n\n\"Hopefully looking to do it again,\" he said. \"I don't know if it's ever been done, but it would be kind of a cool thing.\"\n\nWinning back to back in the majors on three occasions has been done. Tiger Woods did it four times - the Masters (2001-02), the PGA Championship (1999-2000 and 2006-07) and the British Open (2005-06). Just not at the U.S. Open.\n\nWoods never said it was easy. It never is. Koepka likes it that way.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf\n\nCaptain Brooks Koepka, of Smash GC, hit from the 10th tee during the final round of LIV Golf Singapore at Sentosa Golf Club, Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Sentosa, Singapore. {"uri": "2024-05-348179190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "19:58:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T19:58:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:07:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/7/brooks-koepka-cuts-to-chase-with-his-talking-done-/", "title": "Brooks Koepka cuts to the chase with his talking done on the course", "body": "Brooks Koepka leaves the bluster to everyone else at LIV Golf. He cares about only his golf, especially when it's not going the way he wants.\n\nHe was burning inside a year ago when he played not to lose in the final round of the Masters and watched his two-shot lead turn into a four-shot loss. He vowed not to let that happen again, and he delivered a month later by claiming his fifth major title at the PGA Championship.\n\nKoepka found more motivation in failure already this year. That he was an afterthought in five LIV Golf events wasn't nearly as irritating as being a no-show at Augusta National. He failed to break par in any round and beat only 10 players who made the cut.\n\nHe was asked in Singapore how his game was trending.\n\n\"Clearly not very good, with Augusta the way that went,\" Koepka said, living up to his reputation of cutting to the chase. \"I kind of felt like I wasted all the time from December until then. Just keep grinding away, keep doing the work, and hopefully, something will turn around.\"\n\nAnd it did.\n\nHe made 17 birdies over three rounds in Singapore, was never seriously challenged on the final day and won by two shots. He referred to the Masters as a wake-up call.\n\nIt might be that way for others, too, especially with the PGA Championship at Valhalla next on the docket.\n\nKoepka is the first player to win four LIV Golf titles.\n\nThat doesn't make him the betting favorite at the PGA Championship. Scottie Scheffler has won four times in the last two months against far stronger fields (and over 72 holes) -- in two signature events, The Players Championship and the Masters.\n\nThe search is for who can stop him, and a couple of candidates have emerged in recent weeks as Scheffler waits at home in Dallas for the birth of his first child.\n\nRory McIlroy won in New Orleans, albeit a team event with Shane Lowry, and restored some of the fun in golf that had been sorely missing. He won the last time the PGA Championship was at Valhalla, a wild finish in the dark with McIlroy joining the group ahead -- Phil Mickelson and Rickie Fowler, both still with hopes of winning -- in an effort to finish.\n\nLudvig Aberg is the best futures bet on challenging Scheffler. He's a month away from completing one year as a pro and already is No. 6 in the world ranking with two wins and a Ryder Cup celebration. In his first major, he was runner-up to Scheffler at the Masters.\n\nBut there's something fascinating about Koepka, particularly in the majors, and whenever he seems to have a chip on his shoulder that he puts there himself.\n\nHe once said majors were the easiest to win because they effectively had the smallest fields by process of elimination. Koepka figured he was flat-out better than half of the 156-man field and half of those guys would be off their game. Then he began to factor in how can they handle the pressure. By his math, it was only a few guys left to beat.\n\nTwo days after he made those comments, Koepka opened with 63-65 at Bethpage Black in the 2019 PGA Championship to set a major championship record for 36 holes. He set PGA Championship records for largest 36- and 54-hole leads.\n\nThe back nine on Sunday wasn't pretty when he made four straight bogeys and fans on Long Island began cheering for more. Unfazed, Koepka closed it out for a two-shot victory.\n\n\"It's New York. What do you expect when you're half-choking it away?\" Koepka said.\n\nNo bull. No bluster.\n\nHe doesn't always deliver. There was the shade he threw Dustin Johnson's way the following year at Harding Park when Koepka was trying to become the first player to win three straight PGA Championship titles in stroke play.\n\nHe was two shots behind Johnson after 54 holes and said: \"When I've been in this position before, I've capitalized. He's only won one. I'm playing good. I don't know, we'll see.\" Koepka didn't make a birdie until the 12th hole, shot 74 and tied for 29th.\n\nHe failed to take down 50-year-old Mickelson at Kiawah Island. He lost a 54-hole lead to Jon Rahm at the Masters last year.\n\nBut he's always there.\n\nThere's still a loose notion that LIV Golf's format, schedule and guaranteed riches don't prepare its players for the majors. The results don't bear that out -- three LIV players finished in the top 10 at the Masters this year and last, three in the PGA Championship last year, two in the U.S. Open.\n\nAnd it should never apply to Koepka. His record in the majors, when he is healthy, is daunting.\n\n\"I think the big thing that kind of separates me is my ability to lock in and go someplace where I think a lot of guys can't go,\" he said in Singapore.\n\nThat ability allowed him to win one U.S. Open by tying the record score to par (16 under) at Erin Hills, and win the next year with a score over par at Shinnecock Hills. He also won back-to-back in the PGA Championship.\n\n\"Hopefully looking to do it again,\" he said. \"I don't know if it's ever been done, but it would be kind of a cool thing.\"\n\nWinning back-to-back in the majors on three occasions has been done. Tiger Woods did it four times -- the Masters (2001-02), the PGA Championship (1999-2000 and 2006-07) and the British Open (2005-06). Just not at the U.S. Open.\n\nWoods never said it was easy. It never is. {"uri": "8117479711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:38:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:38:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:38:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://talksport.com/sport/1859500/pga-championship-2024-betting-tips-masters-favourites-betting-tips-odds-koepka-mcilroy-aberg/", "title": "The favourites for PGA Championship glory as Koepka defends Wanamaker Trophy", "body": "The second golf major of the summer is coming up with the 2024 PGA Championship taking centre-stage at the famous Valhalla Golf Club.\n\nThe PGA Championship is regarded as having the strongest field in golf as it invites twenty PGA club or teaching professionals rather than amateurs like the other majors.\n\nBrooks Koepka is the defending champion this year following his brilliant two-shot win at Oak Hill last May.\n\nKoepka claimed his fifth major title after seeing off challenges from Viktor Hovland and Scottie Scheffler during a dominant week in New York.\n\nBut world No.1 Scheffler is the favourite heading to Kentucky after his stunning victory at The Masters last month.\n\nBut could a key change in Scheffler's personal life open the door to his PGA Tour and LIV Golf rivals?\n\nScheffler is by far the best golfer on the planet.\n\nAs well as his imperious win at Augusta, he has also won at two more prestigious events this year with victories at The Players and the RBC Heritage.\n\nBut the 27-year-old has not played since that win at Hilton Head due to the fact his wife Meredith is about to give birth to their first child.\n\nScheffler has repeatedly said that he will not miss that important life event for anything and has elected to miss the Wells Fargo Championship this week.\n\nMeredith will give birth any day now - if she hasn't already - meaning Scheffler should have time to refocus on his golf.\n\nBut should the little one make him wait longer than expected, he may well miss out at Valhalla.\n\nMcIlroy finished 16 shots behind Scheffler at The Masters last month as another major passed him by.\n\nInfamously, McIlroy has been stuck on four major titles since August 2014, having 20 top ten finishes since.\n\nBut his last victory on the biggest stage actually came at the 2014 PGA Championship and at Valhalla!\n\nMcIlroy will hope his course knowledge and good experiences in Louisville can finally help end his major drought.\n\nThe 35-year-old is also heading to the tournament having turned a corner in terms of form following a morale-boosting win alongside friend Shane Lowry at the Zurich Classic.\n\nMcIlroy is looking for his 40th career win and it would be fitting if he could bring up such a milestone back at Valhalla.\n\nRahm has not tasted victory since his Masters win in 2023.\n\nHe claimed second at The Open last summer but is yet to take a victory on the LIV Golf tour and finished a lowly T45 at Augusta last month.\n\nMany will say his defection to the breakaway tour has hampered his game and the stats would back that up.\n\nBut the Spaniard was superb at the Ryder Cup and still has the perfect game for tough tournaments like the PGA Championship.\n\nRahm, the 2021 US Open champion, will be eager to hit back at his critics and prove he is still a major-calibre player in Kentucky.\n\nStill just 24 years old, Aberg has rocketed up the rankings over the past two years.\n\nHe made his major debut at the Masters last month, finishing a brilliant solo second behind Scheffler and even had more than a sniff of winning it.\n\nThe Swede is a generational talent with the long-game power, short-game nous and level-headed temperament needed to excel at the top of the game.\n\nHis last trophy came at the RSM Classic in November and he'll be itching to return to the winner's circle.\n\nMany will be backing him to go one step further than he did at The Masters and win on his PGA Championship debut.\n\nKoepka is undoubtedly the best golfer outside of the PGA Tour right now.\n\nHe won his fourth LIV Golf event in Singapore recently and has already proven that LIV players are good enough to claim major glory.\n\nKoepka's win at Oak Hill last May was historic.\n\nHe joined Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods as the only players to win three PGA titles and became the 20th player to win five majors.\n\nA sixth major title would see him equal the hauls of legends Lee Trevino, Nick Faldo and Phil Mickelson and further boost his claim as a modern-day great.\n\nHe had an underwhelming Masters but loves playing at tough, long American courses and will no doubt be in the mix again come Sunday at Valhalla.", "source": {"uri": "talksport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "talkSPORT"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-05-348021562", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:50:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:50:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:54:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.aol.com/greg-norman-phil-mickelson-interesting-155407404.html", "title": "Greg Norman and Phil Mickelson make for an interesting week on LIV Golf", "body": "Greg Norman and Phil Mickelson make for an interesting week on LIV GolfDOUG FERGUSONMay 7, 2024 at 11:54 AM\n\nLIV Golf had another active week before and after Brooks Koepka won in Singapore for his first title of the year.\n\nGreg Norman, the CEO of the Saudi-funded league, had a couple of bold comments in an interview with Bloomberg that indicated LIV isn't going anywhere.\n\nHe said Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the governor of the Public Investment Fund that has invested billions in the PGA Tour's rival league, told him LIV Golf \"will be well and truly in operation well past his death.\"\n\n\"And he's a young guy,\" Norman said.\n\nThe Shark also tossed out the idea of LIV buying golf courses that would serve as the home venue of teams, much like in team sports. And to top it off, he challenged criticism that no one was tuning in to watch.\n\n\"What's the definition of tuning in?\" he asked Bloomberg. \"To an 18-year-old, to a 25-year-old, tuning in may be 12 seconds on the phone. 'Let me see this, then we'll go back and do that, and then I'll come back over here and do another 14 seconds on this.'\n\n\"That to me is tuning in,\" he said. \"That to me is a market that's enormously wealthy, right? And enormously influential in the direction where we're going.\"\n\nAs for the majors, let Phil Mickelson take it from there. He saw an X post on Sunday that said LIV should make it a priority to get its players access to the majors.\n\nMickelson replied in a post that he later deleted: \"Maybe some LIV players won't be missed. But what if NONE of the LIV players played? Would they be missed? What about next year when more great players join? Or the following year? At some point they will care and will have to answer to sponsors and television. FAAFO.\"\n\nThe abbreviation is slang for \"(Expletive) around and find out.\" The next day, Talor Gooch and David Puig were among LIV players to accept invitations to the PGA Championship.\n\nIt wasn't all saucy.\n\nLIV announced that longtime Pepsi executive Adam Harter would be its new chief marketing officer. That follows appointments of a chief financial officer, two executive vice presidents and two other hires.\n\nIt certainly doesn't sound as though LIV Golf is going anywhere.\n\nGOOD TIMING FOR LPGA\n\nA deal announced six months ago is paying dividends for the LPGA Tour this week.\n\nESPN+ and the LPGA signed a two-year agreement for eight tournaments to be streamed live through the 2025 season. In a fortuitous turn of events, one of those tournaments is the Cognizant Founders Cup.\n\nAttention figures to be high as Nelly Korda tries to set the LPGA Tour record with six straight victories. Her victory in the Chevron Championship three weeks ago tied the mark shared by Nancy Lopez and Annika Sorenstam.\n\nGolf Channel typically provides LPGA coverage. But the PGA Tour has two tournaments (Wells Fargo Championship and Myrtle Beach), and the PGA Tour Champions has a major championship (Regions Tradition).\n\nThe Cognizant Cup originally was scheduled to be shown on tape delay (7 p.m. to 9 p.m. on weeknights, 8:30 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. on the weekend). Now it will be available on the NBC Sports App and Peacock.\n\nESPN+ will stream nearly 40 hours of featured group coverage, from 8 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. on the weekday rounds, then from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on the weekend. Amy Rogers is leading the all-female primary broadcast team.\n\nABERG OUT\n\nThe next signature event on the PGA Tour will be without the Masters champion and the runner-up. Scottie Scheffler never planned to play the Wells Fargo Championship because his wife is due to give birth to their first child. The surprise was Ludvig Aberg.\n\nThe rising star from Sweden announced Monday he was withdrawing, releasing limited details except to say he has a \"knee issue\" that requires rest.\n\n\"After consulting with my doctors, we think it's best that I take some additional time to rest,\" Aberg said in a statement, adding that he looked forward to playing in the PGA Championship at Valhalla next week.\n\nHe is not being replaced at Quail Hollow because Peter Malnati would be next in line among the top 10 available in the FedEx Cup, and Malnati already is eligible as a PGA Tour winner this year. That leaves a 69-man field -- meaning someone will go off as a single -- for the third consecutive signature event.\n\nTGL BY THE BAY\n\nSan Francisco's four-man team for the tech-driven TGL league has a basketball background for a golf squad from all over the world.\n\nFormer Milwaukee Bucks co-owner Marc Lasry's Avenue Sports Fund owns The Bay Golf Club, along with Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Andre Iguodala, two current and one retired Golden State Warriors players.\n\nThe roster features Ludvig Aberg of Sweden, Shane Lowry of Ireland, Min Woo Lee of Australia and Wyndham Clark of Denver.\n\nAll the matches will be played in Florida at an indoor arena that will be ready for the January launch at SoFi Center. The indoor league, to be broadcast in prime time on ESPN and ESPN+, was delayed a year when an inflatable roof collapsed.\n\n\"We believe that The Bay Golf Club will be a beloved team in Northern California and beyond,\" Lasry said.\n\nTGL is the creation of TMRW Sports launched by Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy.\n\nSIMPSON BENEFITS\n\nWebb Simpson is playing his eighth tournament of the year at the Wells Fargo Championship, four of them by getting a sponsor exemption to the $20 million signature events.\n\nIt's easy to suggest it's a perk from serving on the PGA Tour board. Simpson got an exemption to the Arnold Palmer Invitational (he's a former Palmer/Buddy Worsham scholarship recipient at Wake Forest), RBC Heritage (past champion from 2020) and the Wells Fargo Championship (he's a member at Quail Hollow).\n\nThe suspect exemption was from the AT&T Pebble Beach, especially when Gary Woodland did not get one as he recovers from brain surgery and won his U.S. Open at Pebble Beach.\n\nBut there's no doubting the potential benefit, even without finishing better than 30th.\n\nSimpson has made the cut in three regular tournaments, earning $63,606 (19 FedEx Cup points). In the three signature events with small fields, he has made $270,125 (74 FedEx Cup points).\n\nHe is No. 151 in the FedEx Cup standings.\n\nDIVOTS\n\nAshley Shaw, a 15-year-old amateur from Arizona, makes her LPGA debut this week in the Cognizant Founders Cup. She won the John Shippen Cognizant Cup on Monday at Upper Montclair to earn a spot in the field. The John Shippen series was created to provide playing opportunities on the LPGA and PGA Tour for top Black golfers. ... The most recent stretch of the Aon Swing Five for signature events was heavily weighted toward the last tournament. So it's no surprise that the top three players from the CJ Cup Byron Nelson -- Taylor Pendrith, Ben Kohles and Alex Noren -- moved into the top five on the list and earned a spot in the Wells Fargo Championship. Chad Ramey and Martin Trainer, who lost in a playoff at the team event in New Orleans, got bumped out. ... The Women's Scottish Open returns to Dundonald Links, about 20 minutes from Royal Troon, for the third straight year on Aug. 15-18. ... Aaron Rai closed with a 64 in the Byron Nelson, which moved him to No. 69 in the PGA Championship Points list and assured his spot at Valhalla.\n\nSTAT OF THE WEEK\n\nTaylor Pendrith became the fifth player this year to be outside the top 100 in the world ranking when he won a PGA Tour event with full FedEx Cup points.\n\nFINAL WORD\n\n\"The pure enjoyment that you get from having kids, there is nothing like it. The stress that you get from having kids, there is nothing like it.\" -- Jason Day, a former world No. 1 and father of five.\n\n___\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8118908169", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:04:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:04:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:04:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://golfweek.usatoday.com/2024/05/09/brooks-koepka-jon-rahm-talor-gooch-midway-point-liv-golf-2024-season/", "title": "At the turn: Brooks Koepka, Jon Rahm, Talor Gooch, more at midway point of LIV Golf's 2024 season", "body": "LIV Golf has reached the midway point of its 2024 season and the Saudi-backed league continues to show no signs of slowing,\n\nAs talks between the PGA Tour and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, which finances LIV, continue to drag on, LIV continues to grow, adding players, as it did last offseason with Jon Rahm, Tyrrell Hatton and Adrian Meronk, and growing its business side, as it has this year by adding a chief financial officer and chief marketing officer, among others.\n\nAnd LIV's chief pot stirrer, at least among the players, Phil Mickelson, continues to drop hints about more raids on the PGA Tour.\n\nMickelson responded to a tweet about the lack of LIV golfers in the major championships - that did not age well with the PGA of America announcing Tuesday it invited seven more to play in the PGA Championship, bringing the number to 16 - by responding: \"What about next year when more great players join? Or the following year?\"\n\nMickelson and LIV's chief executive officer and commissioner Greg Norman made the same promise following the 2022 and 2023 seasons. It didn't go so well two years ago, but the league made up for that last offseason by signing Rahm and Hatton.\n\nWith seven events down and seven remaining in LIV's third season - next up Houston June 7-9 - some observations on the league that has its headquarters in West Palm Beach:\n\nKoepka ramping up for another major\n\nBrooks Koepka's win last weekend at Singapore makes him the first LIV golfer with four career titles on that circuit. But the number he really cares about is five, as in his number of major championships.\n\nThe Jupiter, Florida, resident will chase his sixth major at Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, the site of the 2024 PGA Championship. Three of his major wins are the PGA Championship, including last year at Oak Hill outside of Rochester, New York.\n\nBrooks Koepka celebrates on the podium after winning the 2024 LIV Golf Singapore at Sentosa Golf Club. (Photo: Lionel Ng/Getty Images)\n\n\"Everything was really solid,\" Koepka said following his win at Singapore. \"I didn't really think I made too many mistakes. It's a great feeling when it kind of feels easy, if you get what I'm saying.\n\n\"I like the way things are trending.\"\n\nNiemann leads points race\n\nJoaquin Niemann is carrying his strong offseason that got him invites to the Masters and PGA Championship into the LIV season.\n\nNiemann leads the individual standings with 134.4 points. Rahm is second at 98.17. Niemann has two wins and has been in the top 10 in all but one event.\n\nCrushers, with captain Bryson DeChambeau, Anirban Lahiri, Paul Casey and Charles Howell III, lead the team standings.\n\nMoney, money, money, money\n\nNiemann also leads the money list thanks to those two titles that earned him $4 million each. With $10,888,000 in prize money, he leads Dean Burmester ($7,258,013) and Koepka ($6,080,500).\n\nNiemann has earned $19.2 million in less than two years on LIV (he joined in August 2022). He made $15.1 million in prize money in 122 events on the PGA Tour dating back to his first event in 2017.\n\nAt times, Rahm misses PGA Tour\n\nRahm boosted LIV's profile after leaving the PGA Tour in December. He is off to a strong start in his new league with top-10 finishes in all seven events, including twice tying for third.\n\nAnd while Rahm has never mentioned regretting the decision that will net him a reported $550 million over three years including bonuses - plus prize money of which he already has topped $5 million this season - he did admit to being \"emotional\" when thinking about what he has given up.\n\nRahm said driving by TPC Scottsdale in his hometown, and knowing he is ineligible for events like the WM Phoenix Open and those in Palm Springs and at Torrey Pines in California is difficult.\n\nThen he thinks about a half billion dollars and all that goes away.\n\nAnthony Kim return not going well on course\n\nAlthough results are the least important part of Anthony Kim joining LIV and getting his life back in order, it can't be ignored that the one-time world No. 6 continues to struggle on the course.\n\nKim has played five events as a wild card and has not finished better than 50th in the 54-man fields, placing 52nd, 54th, 53rd, 50th and 52nd. Still, his combined 52-over par has earned him $260,000.\n\n\"As important as golf is, I just want to be in the right mental place,\" Kim said at the LIV event at Doral. \"I would get upset if I played a bad round of golf for two weeks, and it would bother me, eat at me.\n\n\"(Now) I could care less what I shot. I know that the next day, I'm going to lace up any shoes or not lace up my shoes and go try my best again.\"\n\nGooch gets his wish\n\nTalor Gooch enjoyed playing the martyr this season for being left out of the majors. But LIV's 2023 individual champion finally got his wish.\n\nGooch announced on social media Monday he will be headed to Valhalla next week, thanking the PGA of America for the invite. The PGA of America confirmed that invite on Tuesday, along with six more LIV golfers.\n\nLIV now has 16 golfers in the PGA Championship, three more than in the recent Masters. Next up is the U.S. Open in June at Pinehurst. Of LIV's 46 non-exempt players for the U.S. Open, 35 are scheduled to compete in qualifying including Niemann, Sergio Garcia, Patrick Reed and Harold Varner III.\n\nGooch said he was not joining them. Perhaps he knows that may not be necessary.\n\nWestwood fading fast\n\nLee Westwood, 51, is the poster child for the fading star who decided to cash in one last time by joining LIV. A former world No. 1, Westwood was one of LIV's original golfers. He did so midway through a season (2021-22) in which he had one top-25 finish in 10 events.\n\nWestwood is one of just three LIV golfers who have yet to earn a point this season, along with Kim and Hudson Swafford. His best finish is T-32 in LIV's season opener at Mayakoba. Only the top 24 finishers in each event earn points. If it weren't for Westwood being a team captain he would be in danger of facing relegation.", "source": {"uri": "golfweek.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Golfweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... Update: Suspect in highway shooting found dead after pursuit, I-80 standoff BottleRock organizers break down closure, access details around Napa's new Festival La Onda Napa County Planning Commission denies controversial Vida Valiente winery application One family, one storefront: Clemente's restaurant moves to new location in Napa Young in Napa: The problem with Napa drivers Napa County starts rezoning for multi-family housing sites Police: Two arrested after vehicle pursuit in Napa Napa tackles William Cole winery code compliance, growth requests Napa Land Trust gains 1,300-acre Mead Ranch on Atlas Peak An 'incredible ride': Napa Valley small business owner bakes gluten-free bread, pastries and more. Woman gets six-year prison term for fatal 2022 Napa car crash All smoke and mirrors? Police records reveal Napa dispensaries are chill Police: Man arrested after armed robbery of American Canyon convenience store Napa County plans to turn pharma building into government home Repairs on historic downtown Napa church set for completion in August\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. {"uri": "8115975025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:00:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:00:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:59:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/aikenstandard/sports/golf/analysis-brooks-koepka-has-a-big-game-he-doesnt-need-a-lot-of-words/article_d1d1d306-5ae8-54d1-bc6e-00b2ee3492de.html", "title": "Analysis: Brooks Koepka has a big game. He doesn't need a lot of words", "body": "Brooks Koepka leaves the bluster to everyone else at LIV Golf. He cares about only his golf, especially when it's not going the way he wants.\n\nHe was burning inside a year ago when he played not to lose in the final round of the Masters and watched his two-shot lead turn into a four-shot loss. He vowed not to let that happen again, and he delivered a month later by claiming his fifth major title at the PGA Championship.\n\nKoepka found more motivation in failure already this year. That he was an afterthought in five LIV Golf events wasn't nearly as irritating as being a no-show at Augusta National. He failed to break par in any round and beat only 10 players who made the cut.\n\nHe was asked in Singapore how is game was trending.\n\n\"Clearly not very good, with Augusta the way that went,\" Koepka said, living up to his reputation of cutting to the chase. \"I kind of felt like I wasted all the time from December until then. Just keep grinding away, keep doing the work, and hopefully something will turn around.\"\n\nAnd it did.\n\nHe made 17 birdies over three rounds in Singapore, was never seriously challenged on the final day and won by two shots. He referred to the Masters as a wake-up call.\n\nIt might be that way for others, too, especially with the PGA Championship at Valhalla next on the docket.\n\nKoepka is the first player to win four LIV Golf titles.\n\nThat doesn't make him the betting favorite at the PGA Championship. Scottie Scheffler has won four times in the last two months against far stronger fields (and over 72 holes) -- in two signature events, The Players Championship and the Masters.\n\nThe search is for who can stop him, and a couple of candidates have emerged in recent weeks as Scheffler waits at home in Dallas for the birth of his first child.\n\nRory McIlroy won in New Orleans, albeit a team event with Shane Lowry, and restored some of the fun in golf that had been sorely missing. He won the last time the PGA Championship was at Valhalla, a wild finish in the dark with McIlroy joining the group ahead -- Phil Mickelson and Rickie Fowler, both still with hopes of winning -- in an effort to finish.\n\nLudvig Aberg is the best futures bet on challenging Scheffler. He's a month away from completing one year as a pro and already is No. 6 in the world ranking with two wins and a Ryder Cup celebration. In his first major, he was runner-up to Scheffler at the Masters.\n\nBut there's something fascinating about Koepka, particularly in the majors, and whenever he seems to have a chip on his shoulder that he puts there himself.\n\nHe once said majors were the easiest to win because they effectively had the smallest fields by process of elimination. Koepka figured he was flat-out better than half of the 156-man field and half of those guys would be off their game. Then he began to factor in how can they handle the pressure. By his math, it was only a few guys left to beat.\n\nSimple.\n\nToday's Top Headlines 1 man dead after shooting on Aiken's Southside Dougherty Road resurfacing project could cause traffic delays on Aiken's Southside Jackson resident finds purpose, fulfillment as foster parent Rolls-Royce adding capacity at Graniteville plant to meet data center backup power demands Business roundup: New Japanese restaurant opens, La Parisienne has new co-owner 2 men arrested in connection with shooting near Hitchcock Animal Hospital Today's events for May 7 Strom Thurmond baseball walks off against Ninety Six to win district title Local Results for May 7 Super fun: Kentucky Derby parties provide boost for charities\n\nAnd then he won another major.\n\nTwo days after he made those comments, Koepka opened with 63-65 at Bethpage Black in the 2019 PGA Championship to set a major championship record for 36 holes. He set PGA Championship records for largest 36- and 54-hole leads.\n\nThe back nine on Sunday wasn't pretty when he made four straight bogeys and fans on Long Island began cheering for more. Unfazed, Koepka closed it out for a two-shot victory.\n\n\"It's New York. What do you expect when you're half-choking it away?\" Koepka said.\n\nNo bull. No bluster.\n\nHe doesn't always deliver. There was the shade he threw Dustin Johnson's way the following year at Harding Park when Koepka was trying to become the first player to win three straight PGA Championship titles in stroke play.\n\nHe was two shots behind Johnson after 54 holes and said: \"When I've been in this position before, I've capitalized. He's only won one. I'm playing good. I don't know, we'll see.\" Koepka didn't make a birdie until the 12th hole, shot 74 and tied for 29th.\n\nHe failed to take down 50-year-old Mickelson at Kiawah Island. He lost a 54-hole lead to Jon Rahm at the Masters last year.\n\nBut he's always there.\n\nThere's still a loose notion that LIV Golf's format, schedule and guaranteed riches don't prepare its players for the majors. The results don't bear that out -- three LIV players finished in the top 10 at the Masters this year and last, three in the PGA Championship last year, two in the U.S. Open.\n\nAnd it should never apply to Koepka. His record in the majors, when he is healthy, is daunting.\n\n\"I think the big thing that kind of separates me is my ability to lock in and go someplace where I think a lot of guys can't go,\" he said in Singapore.\n\nThat ability allowed him to win one U.S. Open by tying the record score to par (16 under) at Erin Hills, and win the next year with a score over par at Shinnecock Hills. He also won back-to-back in the PGA Championship.\n\n\"Hopefully looking to do it again,\" he said. \"I don't know if it's ever been done, but it would be kind of a cool thing.\"\n\nWinning back to back in the majors on three occasions has been done. Tiger Woods did it four times -- the Masters (2001-02), the PGA Championship (1999-2000 and 2006-07) and the British Open (2005-06). Just not at the U.S. Open.\n\nWoods never said it was easy. It never is. {"uri": "8116311841", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:05:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:05:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:04:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/sports/professional/golf-pga-championship-liv-tour-tiger-woods-reed-valhalla-louisville/article_bbc43ba6-e187-504c-8937-5b183bfb8a09.html", "title": "PGA Championship invites seven LIV players", "body": "DOUG FERGUSON Associated Press\n\nThe PGA Championship officially has Tiger Woods in a field released Tuesday that includes invitations to seven players from Saudi-funded LIV Golf, giving the major the entire top 100 in the world ranking at Valhalla next week.\n\nThe PGA of America strives to have the top 100 in the world to maintain its reputation for having the strongest field of the four majors, although it is not part of the criteria.\n\nInstead, the PGA uses a catch-all category of \"special invitations.\" The group of LIV players includes Patrick Reed, whose tie for 12th in the Masters moved him inside the top 100. He is at No. 92, and the invitation keeps alive his streak of playing every major since the 2014 Masters.\n\nThe PGA Championship returns to Valhalla in Louisville, Kentucky, for the fourth time on May 16-19. Rory McIlroy won at Valhalla the last time it was there in 2014. The course is best known for Woods winning a playoff over Bob May in 2000 for his third straight major.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hard Rock ramping up hiring efforts Nominations reach 29 for Gene \"Pappy\" Thompson Award Former UVA Wise College Board Member Gives $1 Million to school PREP BASEBALL: Falcons finish season sweep of John Battle PREP GIRLS BASKETBALL: Rex Parker steps down as Lebanon's coach, a role he'd held since 1996 PREP SPORTS: Bradley Ricker steps down as football coach at John Battle, will remain as AD. Mike Danser (boys basketball), Sydney McKinney (volleyball) are new head coaches for Trojans THURSDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Abingdon (baseball), John Battle (softball) clinch Mountain 7 District titles; Tennessee High girls tennis team claims district crown; Lee High baseball team scores 29 runs; Trajan Cannon (Patrick Henry), Kailyn Breeding and Cooper Hurst (Richlands) also among stars TUESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Brandon Edwards (J.I. Burton), Matthew Nunley (Honaker), Tyler Hash (Tazewell), Maya Owens (Holston), Reagan Evans (Rural Retreat), Erin Rasnake (Lebanon), Taylor Preston (Marion), Braelyn Scammell (Patrick Henry), Chase Wolfenbarger (Tennessee High) among notable performers PREP BASEBALL: Abingdon gets 2-0 verdict over Virginia High as freshman catcher Judge Dillow, strong pitching overrule Bearcats HISTORY WITH HAYES | 'Time after time': J.J. Kelly won its fourth straight state title 40 years ago. No VHSL baseball team has achieved a four-peat before or since. WEDNESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Blair Rutherford and Alex Brown (Patrick Henry), Taylor Childress (John Battle), Emmaleigh Banks (Eastside), Will Rollins (Rye Cove), Ella Moss (Marion), Madyson Doss (Sullivan East), Hayden Baker (Ridgeview) among stars PREP BOYS SOCCER: Lebanon's Michael Reece gives soccer a shot and is now stopping shots as goalkeeper for Pioneers PREP SOFTBALL: Union beats rain, John Battle as Bears bash four homers in 14-1 win HIGH SCHOOL BASEBALL: Chilhowie extends perfect mark in the Hogoheegee District MOTORSPORTS: Stanley is a hometown hero at Lonesome Pine\n\nJoaquin Niemann, who won the Australian Open in December and has two LIV Golf wins this year, already received an invitation. The surprise was Talor Gooch announcing in an X post on Monday that he had received an invitation.\n\nIt was a sign the PGA of America's selection committee was looking at LIV results on their own, as Gooch doesn't play much outside the Saudi league. He won three times on LIV in 2023 and won the season points list.\n\nOther invitations went to Dean Burmester, Lucas Herbert, Adrian Meronk, all of them inside the top 100 in the world. The seventh invitation went to David Puig, the 22-year-old from Spain who is No. 106 in the world ranking. Puig has finished in the top 10 in six of his last seven tournaments on the Asian Tour, including two wins.\n\nLIV will be represented by 16 players, down from 18 a year ago.\n\nThere might have been one more, except British Open champion Louis Oosthuizen turned down his invitation. Oosthuizen, who is No. 125 in the world, won twice late last year in South Africa in tournaments co-sanctioned by the European tour.\n\nHis manager, Carlos Rodriguez, said in a text message that Oosthuizen already had some personal commitments.\n\nThe LIV group includes defending champion Brooks Koepka, who goes for a fourth PGA Championship title. He is the only active LIV player to win a major.\n\nKerry Haigh, the championship director for the PGA of America, has said he would consider deserving players from tours around the world. Invitations were given to Tim Widing of Sweden, who has won consecutive tournaments on the Korn Ferry Tour.\n\nAnother invitation went to Kazuma Kobori, a 22-year-old born in Japan who now plays under the New Zealand flag. He has won three times this year in the Webex Players Series on the PGA Tour of Australasia.\n\nThe field has 21 club professionals -- 20 from the PGA Professional Championship last week, and Michael Block, who qualified by finishing among the top 15 last year at Oak Hill.\n\nThe PGA is keeping two spots open in case the winners of the Wells Fargo Championship and the Myrtle Beach Classic are not already eligible. Only four players in the 69-man field at the Wells Fargo Championship have not qualified. The first alternate is Doug Ghim.\n\nTags Dcc Wire Lee-national Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this {"uri": "2024-05-347967475", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:00:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:00:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:54:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/greg-norman-phil-mickelson-interesting-155407240.html", "title": "Greg Norman and Phil Mickelson make for an interesting week on LIV Golf", "body": "LIV Golf had another active week before and after Brooks Koepka won in Singapore for his first title of the year.\n\nGreg Norman, the CEO of the Saudi-funded league, had a couple of bold comments in an interview with Bloomberg that indicated LIV isn't going anywhere.\n\nHe said Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the governor of the Public Investment Fund that has invested billions in the PGA Tour's rival league, told him LIV Golf \"will be well and truly in operation well past his death.\"\n\n\"And he's a young guy,\" Norman said.\n\nThe Shark also tossed out the idea of LIV buying golf courses that would serve as the home venue of teams, much like in team sports. And to top it off, he challenged criticism that no one was tuning in to watch.\n\n\"What's the definition of tuning in?\" he asked Bloomberg. \"To an 18-year-old, to a 25-year-old, tuning in may be 12 seconds on the phone. 'Let me see this, then we'll go back and do that, and then I'll come back over here and do another 14 seconds on this.'\n\n\"That to me is tuning in,\" he said. \"That to me is a market that's enormously wealthy, right? And enormously influential in the direction where we're going.\"\n\nAs for the majors, let Phil Mickelson take it from there. He saw an X post on Sunday that said LIV should make it a priority to get its players access to the majors.\n\nMickelson replied in a post that he later deleted: \"Maybe some LIV players won't be missed. But what if NONE of the LIV players played? Would they be missed? What about next year when more great players join? Or the following year? At some point they will care and will have to answer to sponsors and television. FAAFO.\"\n\nThe abbreviation is slang for \"(Expletive) around and find out.\" The next day, Talor Gooch and David Puig were among LIV players to accept invitations to the PGA Championship.\n\nIt wasn't all saucy.\n\nLIV announced that longtime Pepsi executive Adam Harter would be its new chief marketing officer. That follows appointments of a chief financial officer, two executive vice presidents and two other hires.\n\nIt certainly doesn't sound as though LIV Golf is going anywhere.\n\nGOOD TIMING FOR LPGA\n\nA deal announced six months ago is paying dividends for the LPGA Tour this week.\n\nESPN+ and the LPGA signed a two-year agreement for eight tournaments to be streamed live through the 2025 season. In a fortuitous turn of events, one of those tournaments is the Cognizant Founders Cup.\n\nAttention figures to be high as Nelly Korda tries to set the LPGA Tour record with six straight victories. Her victory in the Chevron Championship three weeks ago tied the mark shared by Nancy Lopez and Annika Sorenstam.\n\nGolf Channel typically provides LPGA coverage. But the PGA Tour has two tournaments (Wells Fargo Championship and Myrtle Beach), and the PGA Tour Champions has a major championship (Regions Tradition).\n\nThe Cognizant Cup originally was scheduled to be shown on tape delay (7 p.m. to 9 p.m. on weeknights, 8:30 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. on the weekend). Now it will be available on the NBC Sports App and Peacock.\n\nESPN+ will stream nearly 40 hours of featured group coverage, from 8 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. on the weekday rounds, then from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on the weekend. Amy Rogers is leading the all-female primary broadcast team.\n\nABERG OUT\n\nThe next signature event on the PGA Tour will be without the Masters champion and the runner-up. Scottie Scheffler never planned to play the Wells Fargo Championship because his wife is due to give birth to their first child. The surprise was Ludvig Aberg.\n\nThe rising star from Sweden announced Monday he was withdrawing, releasing limited details except to say he has a \"knee issue\" that requires rest.\n\n\"After consulting with my doctors, we think it's best that I take some additional time to rest,\" Aberg said in a statement, adding that he looked forward to playing in the PGA Championship at Valhalla next week.\n\nHe is not being replaced at Quail Hollow because Peter Malnati would be next in line among the top 10 available in the FedEx Cup, and Malnati already is eligible as a PGA Tour winner this year. That leaves a 69-man field -- meaning someone will go off as a single -- for the third consecutive signature event.\n\nTGL BY THE BAY\n\nSan Francisco's four-man team for the tech-driven TGL league has a basketball background for a golf squad from all over the world.\n\nFormer Milwaukee Bucks co-owner Marc Lasry's Avenue Sports Fund owns The Bay Golf Club, along with Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Andre Iguodala, two current and one retired Golden State Warriors players.\n\nThe roster features Ludvig Aberg of Sweden, Shane Lowry of Ireland, Min Woo Lee of Australia and Wyndham Clark of Denver.\n\nAll the matches will be played in Florida at an indoor arena that will be ready for the January launch at SoFi Center. The indoor league, to be broadcast in prime time on ESPN and ESPN+, was delayed a year when an inflatable roof collapsed.\n\n\"We believe that The Bay Golf Club will be a beloved team in Northern California and beyond,\" Lasry said.\n\nTGL is the creation of TMRW Sports launched by Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy.\n\nSIMPSON BENEFITS\n\nWebb Simpson is playing his eighth tournament of the year at the Wells Fargo Championship, four of them by getting a sponsor exemption to the $20 million signature events.\n\nIt's easy to suggest it's a perk from serving on the PGA Tour board. Simpson got an exemption to the Arnold Palmer Invitational (he's a former Palmer/Buddy Worsham scholarship recipient at Wake Forest), RBC Heritage (past champion from 2020) and the Wells Fargo Championship (he's a member at Quail Hollow).\n\nThe suspect exemption was from the AT&T Pebble Beach, especially when Gary Woodland did not get one as he recovers from brain surgery and won his U.S. Open at Pebble Beach.\n\nBut there's no doubting the potential benefit, even without finishing better than 30th.\n\nSimpson has made the cut in three regular tournaments, earning $63,606 (19 FedEx Cup points). In the three signature events with small fields, he has made $270,125 (74 FedEx Cup points).\n\nAshley Shaw, a 15-year-old amateur from Arizona, makes her LPGA debut this week in the Cognizant Founders Cup. She won the John Shippen Cognizant Cup on Monday at Upper Montclair to earn a spot in the field. The John Shippen series was created to provide playing opportunities on the LPGA and PGA Tour for top Black golfers. ... The most recent stretch of the Aon Swing Five for signature events was heavily weighted toward the last tournament. So it's no surprise that the top three players from the CJ Cup Byron Nelson -- Taylor Pendrith, Ben Kohles and Alex Noren -- moved into the top five on the list and earned a spot in the Wells Fargo Championship. Chad Ramey and Martin Trainer, who lost in a playoff at the team event in New Orleans, got bumped out. ... The Women's Scottish Open returns to Dundonald Links, about 20 minutes from Royal Troon, for the third straight year on Aug. 15-18. ... Aaron Rai closed with a 64 in the Byron Nelson, which moved him to No. 69 in the PGA Championship Points list and assured his spot at Valhalla.\n\nSTAT OF THE WEEK\n\nTaylor Pendrith became the fifth player this year to be outside the top 100 in the world ranking when he won a PGA Tour event with full FedEx Cup points.\n\nFINAL WORD\n\n\"The pure enjoyment that you get from having kids, there is nothing like it. {"uri": "8115912649", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:16:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:16:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:15:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/sports/nation/greg-norman-and-phil-mickelson-make-for-an-interesting-week-on-liv-golf/article_180c19d8-e6c7-5a44-91de-312dbef1de40.html", "title": "Greg Norman and Phil Mickelson make for an interesting week on LIV Golf", "body": "Taylor Pendrith poses with the champion's trophy after winning the Byron Nelson golf tournament in McKinney, Texas, Sunday, May 5, 2024.\n\nLIV Golf had another active week before and after Brooks Koepka won in Singapore for his first title of the year.\n\nGreg Norman, the CEO of the Saudi-funded league, had a couple of bold comments in an interview with Bloomberg that indicated LIV isn't going anywhere.\n\nHe said Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the governor of the Public Investment Fund that has invested billions in the PGA Tour's rival league, told him LIV Golf \"will be well and truly in operation well past his death.\"\n\n\"And he's a young guy,\" Norman said.\n\nThe Shark also tossed out the idea of LIV buying golf courses that would serve as the home venue of teams, much like in team sports. And to top it off, he challenged criticism that no one was tuning in to watch.\n\n\"What's the definition of tuning in?\" he asked Bloomberg. \"To an 18-year-old, to a 25-year-old, tuning in may be 12 seconds on the phone. 'Let me see this, then we'll go back and do that, and then I'll come back over here and do another 14 seconds on this.'\n\n\"That to me is tuning in,\" he said. \"That to me is a market that's enormously wealthy, right? And enormously influential in the direction where we're going.\"\n\nAs for the majors, let Phil Mickelson take it from there. He saw an X post on Sunday that said LIV should make it a priority to get its players access to the majors.\n\nMickelson replied in a post that he later deleted: \"Maybe some LIV players won't be missed. But what if NONE of the LIV players played? Would they be missed? What about next year when more great players join? Or the following year? At some point they will care and will have to answer to sponsors and television. FAAFO.\"\n\nThe abbreviation is slang for \"(Expletive) around and find out.\" The next day, Talor Gooch and David Puig were among LIV players to accept invitations to the PGA Championship.\n\nIt wasn't all saucy.\n\nLIV announced that longtime Pepsi executive Adam Harter would be its new chief marketing officer. That follows appointments of a chief financial officer, two executive vice presidents and two other hires.\n\nIt certainly doesn't sound as though LIV Golf is going anywhere.\n\nGOOD TIMING FOR LPGA\n\nA deal announced six months ago is paying dividends for the LPGA Tour this week.\n\nESPN+ and the LPGA signed a two-year agreement for eight tournaments to be streamed live through the 2025 season. In a fortuitous turn of events, one of those tournaments is the Cognizant Founders Cup.\n\nAttention figures to be high as Nelly Korda tries to set the LPGA Tour record with six straight victories. Her victory in the Chevron Championship three weeks ago tied the mark shared by Nancy Lopez and Annika Sorenstam.\n\nGolf Channel typically provides LPGA coverage. But the PGA Tour has two tournaments (Wells Fargo Championship and Myrtle Beach), and the PGA Tour Champions has a major championship (Regions Tradition).\n\nThe Cognizant Cup originally was scheduled to be shown on tape delay (7 p.m. to 9 p.m. on weeknights, 8:30 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. on the weekend). Now it will be available on the NBC Sports App and Peacock.\n\nESPN+ will stream nearly 40 hours of featured group coverage, from 8 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. on the weekday rounds, then from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on the weekend. Amy Rogers is leading the all-female primary broadcast team.\n\nABERG OUT\n\nThe next signature event on the PGA Tour will be without the Masters champion and the runner-up. Scottie Scheffler never planned to play the Wells Fargo Championship because his wife is due to give birth to their first child. The surprise was Ludvig Aberg.\n\nThe rising star from Sweden announced Monday he was withdrawing, releasing limited details except to say he has a \"knee issue\" that requires rest.\n\n\"After consulting with my doctors, we think it's best that I take some additional time to rest,\" Aberg said in a statement, adding that he looked forward to playing in the PGA Championship at Valhalla next week.\n\nHe is not being replaced at Quail Hollow because Peter Malnati would be next in line among the top 10 available in the FedEx Cup, and Malnati already is eligible as a PGA Tour winner this year. That leaves a 69-man field -- meaning someone will go off as a single -- for the third consecutive signature event.\n\nTGL BY THE BAY\n\nSan Francisco's four-man team for the tech-driven TGL league has a basketball background for a golf squad from all over the world.\n\nFormer Milwaukee Bucks co-owner Marc Lasry's Avenue Sports Fund owns The Bay Golf Club, along with Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Andre Iguodala, two current and one retired Golden State Warriors players.\n\nThe roster features Ludvig Aberg of Sweden, Shane Lowry of Ireland, Min Woo Lee of Australia and Wyndham Clark of Denver.\n\nAll the matches will be played in Florida at an indoor arena that will be ready for the January launch at SoFi Center. The indoor league, to be broadcast in prime time on ESPN and ESPN+, was delayed a year when an inflatable roof collapsed.\n\n\"We believe that The Bay Golf Club will be a beloved team in Northern California and beyond,\" Lasry said.\n\nTGL is the creation of TMRW Sports launched by Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy.\n\nSIMPSON BENEFITS\n\nWebb Simpson is playing his eighth tournament of the year at the Wells Fargo Championship, four of them by getting a sponsor exemption to the $20 million signature events.\n\nIt's easy to suggest it's a perk from serving on the PGA Tour board. Simpson got an exemption to the Arnold Palmer Invitational (he's a former Palmer/Buddy Worsham scholarship recipient at Wake Forest), RBC Heritage (past champion from 2020) and the Wells Fargo Championship (he's a member at Quail Hollow).\n\nThe suspect exemption was from the AT&T Pebble Beach, especially when Gary Woodland did not get one as he recovers from brain surgery and won his U.S. Open at Pebble Beach.\n\nBut there's no doubting the potential benefit, even without finishing better than 30th.\n\nSimpson has made the cut in three regular tournaments, earning $63,606 (19 FedEx Cup points). In the three signature events with small fields, he has made $270,125 (74 FedEx Cup points).\n\nHe is No. 151 in the FedEx Cup standings.\n\nDIVOTS\n\nAshley Shaw, a 15-year-old amateur from Arizona, makes her LPGA debut this week in the Cognizant Founders Cup. She won the John Shippen Cognizant Cup on Monday at Upper Montclair to earn a spot in the field. The John Shippen series was created to provide playing opportunities on the LPGA and PGA Tour for top Black golfers. ... The most recent stretch of the Aon Swing Five for signature events was heavily weighted toward the last tournament. So it's no surprise that the top three players from the CJ Cup Byron Nelson -- Taylor Pendrith, Ben Kohles and Alex Noren -- moved into the top five on the list and earned a spot in the Wells Fargo Championship. Chad Ramey and Martin Trainer, who lost in a playoff at the team event in New Orleans, got bumped out. ... The Women's Scottish Open returns to Dundonald Links, about 20 minutes from Royal Troon, for the third straight year on Aug. 15-18. ... Aaron Rai closed with a 64 in the Byron Nelson, which moved him to No. 69 in the PGA Championship Points list and assured his spot at Valhalla.\n\nSTAT OF THE WEEK\n\nTaylor Pendrith became the fifth player this year to be outside the top 100 in the world ranking when he won a PGA Tour event with full FedEx Cup points.\n\nFINAL WORD\n\n\"The pure enjoyment that you get from having kids, there is nothing like it. The stress that you get from having kids, there is nothing like it.\" -- Jason Day, a former world No. 1 and father of five.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf", "source": {"uri": "hjnews.com", {"uri": "8117530731", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:11:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:11:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:11:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/golf/news/2024-pga-championship-picks-field-predictions-odds-golf-expert-fading-scottie-scheffler-at-valhalla/", "title": "2024 PGA Championship picks, field, predictions, odds: Golf expert fading Scottie Scheffler at Valhalla - CBSSports.com", "body": "Patrick McDonald just locked in his PGA Championship 2024 best bets for the second golf major of the year at Valhalla Golf Club USATSI\n\nBrooks Koepka will attempt to become just the second golfer to repeat as champion twice when the 2024 PGA Championship begins on Thursday, May 16, at Valhalla Golf Club. Koepka won the PGA Championship in 2018 and 2019 before finishing two strokes ahead of Scottie Scheffler and Viktor Hovland last year for the fifth major victory of his career. The two-time U.S. Open champion now has a chance to join Tiger Woods, who went back-to-back in the PGA Championship twice (1999-2000, 2006-07). Koepka will hope to redeem himself after finishing 45th at the Masters last month.\n\nKoepka is 12-1 and Scheffler, who won the Masters for the second time in three years, is the 3-1 favorite in the latest 2024 PGA Championship odds. Jon Rahm is 10-1 in the 2024 PGA Championship betting odds, while two-time winner Rory McIlroy and Ludvig Aberg also are among the top 2024 PGA Championship contenders at 12-1. Before making any 2024 PGA Championship picks or bets, you need to see the PGA Championship 2024 predictions and best bets from golf insider Patrick McDonald.\n\nMcDonald joined CBS Sports as a golf writer in 2022 after stops at NBC Sports and RyderCup.com. Covering the sport from a broader perspective, McDonald still likes to dip his toes into the betting pools on a weekly basis between the PGA Tour, DP World Tour and more. Featured weekly on the Early Wedge, he has given out numerous winners already in 2024, including Jake Knapp (50-1) at the Mexico Open. Anyone who has followed his lead is way up.\n\nNow, McDonald has focused his attention on the 2024 PGA Championship field and has locked in his best bets, top sleepers and favorites to avoid. You can only see them here.\n\nTop 2024 PGA Championship expert picks\n\nOne shocker from McDonald: The expert is fading Scottie Scheffler, who is priced too short to back in such a deep and talented 2024 PGA Championship field. The world No. 1 has won four of the 10 tournaments he's played this season, matching the career-high for victories he set in 2021-22. The four wins came in his last five outings, with the other result in that stretch being runner-up at the Houston Open. \"He's the rightful favorite, as he's the best player in the world by a very wide margin, but I can't get behind Scheffler at +300,\" McDonald told SportsLine. See who else to fade here.\n\nOn the other hand, McDonald loves the value on Xander Schauffele at 20-1. The 30-year-old remains in search of his first win of the season, and also the first in a major of his career. Schauffele has recorded seven top-10 finishes in 11 events this campaign, with his best result being runner-up to Scheffler at The Players. He has posted 12 top-10s in major tournaments and three over the last five, including an eighth-place at The Masters. \"He has been the second-best player in the world from a statistical sense and is as good of a sure thing when it comes to entering the weekend in contention,\" McDonald said. See who else to back here.\n\nHow to make 2024 PGA Championship golf picks\n\nMcDonald has locked in his best bets for the PGA Championship 2024 and also has selected a longshot who's priced well over 50-1. This golfer \"has made significant strides in his game\" this year. If this player can pull off a stunning victory, he would cash in huge for anyone who backs him. You can only see the picks at SportsLine.\n\nSo which players should you target or avoid for the 2024 PGA Championship, and which golfer in the PGA Championship 2024 field could bring a huge payday of more than 50-1?
